I had the chicken breast sandwich which was great also. Very moist and the bread was super fresh. Great selection of beers as well.  Overall, yummy lunch.  Very pleased.
author: Michelle P.

description:
Within 2 hours of me posting this review the GM reached out to me.  
Respect for that simple act.  
More respect for taking time to deal with the problem of bad service clouding the brand.
author: M P.

description: Another great meal before the Giant's game!  Awesome beer selection and great food.  Burger and Cheese Steak are always good.  Excellent onion rings.
author: Mike M.

description: Ridiculously crowded but totally worth it. One of the best beer bars ever (RRB Blind Pig, Firewalker, and other local beers hard to get elsewhere all on draft) AND you can take them inside AT&T Park on your way to Matt Cain's perfect game? Word up. Love that special gate into the stadium.
author: Yan T.

description:
10/14/10...
Came here after dinner for a drink.  Bar staff was really friendly and helpful.  My cocktail (ketel one gimlet) was good.

10/21/10...
Came here during the 9th inning.  Place was PACKED.  Didn't even make it to the bar.  The place was fiercely energetic.
author: Sharon N.

description:
Came here during happy hour to meet up some friends on a sunny, warm day.   The place was PACKED cuz there was a Giants/A's game goin' on.  Even when the doors were open, the body heat was filling the air! Nice thing about this place is that they have an outdoor patio. Lots of TVs to watch the game.  And it's brighter inside compared to Pete's Tavern.  Bartenders are super FRIENDLY with a good sense of humor!

Great spot, great hangout, great location!
author: Diana M.

description:
I always walk through the Public House before heading into the Giants game. It's a great place to stop by for a beer (or two) -- great tip: buy a beer at the Public House and you can take it into the ballpark with you. $6 for a delicious beer at PH verses a $9.25 beer inside the park.

I also ate here for the first time the other night and was pleasently surprised with how good the food was. The mac and chesse was fab and I'd definitely order it again.

The service isn't that great and the prices are pretty steep, but what else can you expect for a sports bar and grill connected to AT&T Park? I wouldn't come here any other time unless I'm on my way to the Giants game. There are way more better local sports bars that are way more reasonably priced. But all in all, the Public was a-ok.
author: Sara K.

description: Nice beer selection, and a fun game-day atmosphere loaded with TVs everywhere- and usually packed with people.  The down-side here is that it is often quite complicated to get drinks amidst the masses.  Seating is nearly impossible before games.  The food is so-so / not great.  The best upside is that a microbrew here is $6 whereas the prices increase to $9-$9.50 once you enter the stadium! So load up here, right?  One other previous secret of mine was that I used to enter here on stadium give-away days (bobble heads, etc), and use the internal entrance directly from the inside of the Public House into the stadium to avoid the massive lines (and get the give-aways).  One of my friends said this is no longer possible, however- so try at your own risk. Anyways, I'll be back (to drink beers, only).
author: Andy S.

description:
Went here because I enjoyed a visit at a public house in another city and it is a convenient location when in the city early for a game.
They were not that busy yet it took forever for us to be greeted, then another lengthy bit of time to get our drinks. The food-runner that brought our food was rude when we told her the items were incorrect. The manager was not pleasant; could have done without his table visit. Had to flag our server down for refills and for our check.
All around worst service I have ever had. I worked as a sever for years and there staff was horrible. Save your time and money and go down the street to Pete's tavern, they are great there.
author: Heather V.

description:
The Public House is a place of extremes....either jam-packed on gameday where you scratch and claw for one of their tasty beers or about as dead as the local morgue when there isn't a game....making you sit there contemplating life and why you're not where all the cool people are.  

Pluses:  best beers in south beach/mission bay...yeah, I'm talking to you 21st Amendment.  Great beer week events....the Ballast Point tap takeover last year was magnificent (and a good crowd despite no game).  The food ain't all that although the burger is very much above average and the mijita nachos are a good value call.

So 3 stars ain't that great when it's really the neighborhood vibe that brings it down, but it is what it is.  If they would tell when they're going to tap the Pliny the Younger this year, I may edit my review (hint...hint).
author: Mike Z.

description:
It seems like this place is pretty new. I came here after a couple of Giants games Memorial Day weekend. The first night (Friday) it was A-OK. The second time we were there (Sunday afternoon) the place was horrible. Two stars it is. 

I don't get to Giants games as often as I should (I'm not a big fan of watching baseball live, but I am a fan of drinking beer and watching sports at the same time, so there you go), but it's a shame that such a prime location so close to the AT&T Park isn't any better than this place. 

Night #1 (Friday): We stroll in around 10. The place is busy, but it wasn't wall-to-wall packed or anything. Seven of us find a table pretty easily. Even though the beer menu is pretty extensive (which is a plus) I go with a Stella. Don't know what the other beer drinkers went with but the non-beer drinkers went with Raspberry Lemonades (alcoholic), which they said were good. One person was a little hungry & got the mac & cheese, which I tasted and was quite good.  The menu in general actually sounds good.  Pretty typical "nicer" sports bar food.  The service was pretty slow. Not insanely bad, but like I said, the place wasn't extremely crowded. 

Day #2 (Sunday): Was here for about a half hour, and never got served. There was nine of us and we were able to sit at a big table with others. NOBODY in our area was happy and I heard several people complaining about the service. The only reason we stayed as long as we did was because a few people ordered drinks at the bar when they got there and we were waiting for them to finish. 

When you're located right next to the ballpark it's a given you're gonna be busy on game days. This place just seemed to have a difficult time handling large crowds. I'm usually not insanely picky about service, but in this case I just can't buy an excuse for (extremely) slow service, because this place should pretty much expect to be busy...
author: George A.

description: We just had our Wedding Reception at the Public House.  The staff was amazing and was quick to respond to any requests we had.  We had the appetizer menu and was plenty of food for our 60+ guests.  Our guest complimented the food and wait staff.  They kept the plates and glasses filled. The managers Nathan and Mark were very helpful and made sure our evening went smoothly.  I highly recommend hosting an event there!  Thanks again Public House for an amazing night!
author: Sean M.

description:
3.5 stars.
Everyone liked this place.  Quite casual and spacious.  There's a bar with a huge selection of beer on tap. We ate in the dining area facing the open kitchen and tried the following:
1. iron skirt steak - Hubby liked it a lot, I thought it was OK.  Tasted like any other steak to me.  Had beans with it. 
2. Onion rings - thin slices but I thought the batter was soggy at times.  Wouldn't order again. (should've read your review beforehand, Genevieve Y.!)
3. Fries - came in a cone and were really good when hot, but at the bottom, got hard and crunchy.
4. Wedge salad - very good and tasty, would order again. Came as a 1/2 of a small lettuce sliced into 2 wedges.
5. Pork sliders - shredded pork in 3 tiny buns. Tasty if you're interested in lighter fares. 
6.  BFF had their potato soup. I had a taste, rather bland to me.

Desserts - can skip this next time.
Everyone had a scoop of their ice cream: peanut butter, Tahitian vanilla and salted choc (this one was the best for me). 
I tried the 'adult root beer float".  The server comp this dessert for me because they didn't get the order right until she fixed it.  It's a small amt of beer poured over a small scoop of vanilla ice cream.  Kind of a rip off given the sm quantity, it's less than 1/2 the size of a root beer you'd get at any A&W.  It tasted odd until you mixed up the beer into the ice cream and turned it into a shake.  I wouldn't order it again and no one at the table liked it after a taste.
Our server was really sweet and that water glass was constantly being filled. 

This is probably going to be our to go place the next time we're in the AT&T park area for a Cirque du Soleil show again.
author: Ry T.

description: Gets pretty crowded on game days and took awhile to get serviced but I like that anything you order inside Public House you can take to go inside the ballpark through the entrance from the restaurant/bar. Whats not to like about quality beer selections at better prices than inside the park.
author: Sarah L.

description:
Hit Public House before the game last night for a better, cheaper beer and a meal at at table rather than on our lap inside. It was crowded inside but we got a table outside most likely because it was pretty chilly. 

We both ordered the Tuna Salad Nicoise an order of Sweet Potato Fries to share and two beer. The salads came out fast but were not great. There was very little tuna, only a few fingerling potatoes, hard boiled eggs and a few olives. Disappointedly, no haricot vert. All and all, it was like bagged lettuce with a few pieces of oil packed albacore tuna and a olive oil dressing for $14. I will not order it again. Sadly, it was the most healthy option on the menu so I am in a corner. Do I go for the hearty meat or eat else where. 

Sweat Potato Fries were fantastic!!! I will head back for beer and fries in the future. 

Would like to see some other light fare on the menu in the future. I know it is the game but I prefer to drink my calories.
author: Janell H.

description:
There are two great things about Public House - the beer selection and the proximity to AT&T Park. Other than that? Meh.

-The place is woefully understaffed (we're talking opening weekend, three hours before game time and I was ignored for a good 20 minutes even though I was seated at a table) and once I was finally acknowledged, my waiter was totally clueless (or overwhelmed. or both)

-Their website said they serve brunch on the weekend but they weren't. 

-My $12 Bacon, Avocado and Lettuce sandwich was anemic and served without a side. Hell, even my Bloody Mary was pretty bad. 

Sorry, Public House...you are officially off the rotation for a pre-game meeting spot.
author: phil h.

description: My gf and I stopped by Public House for a drink after the Giants day game and before the Giants Slumber Party at the park. I definitely needed a drink for that! They have a lot of their own brewed beers as well as imported beers. Some I hadn't even heard of. We grabbed 2 beers and they were only about $12. Nice. Will come back but I imagine this place to be super crazy busy on game days.
author: Katie Anne N.

description: Been here a few times. Service is nice.  Food is good. Great spot to hangout before or after the game since it is right there!  They also serve Humprey Slocombe ice cream!
author: Nicole M.

description:
Great place to watch sports and grab a beer.  The nachos were great, other food we tried was so so (wings, potato croquettes, brownie sundae).  I liked that it is not ridiculously loud and you can actually carry on a conversation.  Tons of TVs and they have the volume on for Niners, Giants and playoff games...  

I wish they had beer descriptions on the menu.  After trying small tastes of two beers, then spending 20 minutes googling several of the beers on the menu, I finally just ordered one I had heard of before and knew I liked...
author: J D.

description:
close to ball park, hard to grab drinks when packed. $$$ for beer

at least they have hitachino beer!! my favorite but $12?!?! X___X
author: Christine M.

description:
Thank you for creating a walk up area. I love this place, but it gets so crowded at times. Thank you for the solution. 

You can also get your beers in plastic cups and walk into the game!

Orange & Black Celebration Ale is on tap from Moylan's...try it!
author: Erin S.

description: After taking a tour of the AT&T Park, we found this place on our exit of the park. I was in need of drink to quench my thirst, and this place was open. It was quiet for around 2PM on a Saturday, maybe it gets busy during the evening or game day.  The bartender was incredibly nice. I asked for what the locals get and he offered three different types of local brew; he even gave me a couple of samplers. The beer was good. And, the environment was great, we sat at the bar and we were surrounding by TVs showing five/six different college ball games (I was in heaven).
author: Jac H.

description: Not bad for a ballpark restaurant, but nothing to write home about. Had the burger which was fine -- but, no tomatoes? Seemed a bit skimpy.
author: David G.

description: Came last night to grab a drink and dinner with some friends. Let's say that after spotting mice all over the dining room floor, we decided to eat elsewhere. When we brought their rodent problem to the staff's attention, we were informed that they knew about it and "there is nothing we can do about it". I believe there is much that can be done. Completely unacceptable. Mice should never be table guests at dinner.
author: Sevanna I.

description:
I was lucky enough to get an invite to the preview of Public House. 
Here is my review: 

First of all, it was all free! So, yes, I did make a pig of myself. 

I had: Philly Cheese Steak, wings, buttermilk onion rings, fries, cinnamon sugar cookie, Tahitian vanilla ice cream, pulled pork sliders, mac 'n' cheese, and raspberry lemonade (with vodka), 
The wife had crab cake sliders and deviled eggs, and more of the lemonade than I did. She also helped me with the wings and rings. 

The Philly was pretty good. I sent the first one back, because they put some kind of sauce on it, and that is just wrong. It was almost as good as the one I used to get at Momo's, and nothing like what you'd get in Philadelphia. I will get one again. 

The pulled pork sliders were OK. They were missing something. BBQ sauce, maybe? 

The wings were very tasty, but the wife felt they could have been cooked a little bit more.   I would order again.

The fries were mediocre, at best, and went half-eaten. 
The onion rings were very good. Can't go wrong with buttermilk.  I will definitely get them again.

The mac 'n' cheese was very good. Not as good as the mac 'n' cheese at Mustard's, but less expensive, too. Wife was a little put off by the bright orange cheese on top.   Another item I would buy again.

The wife enjoyed her food, especially the crab cake sliders. 

The cookie was good, but not really worth $2.00. The ice cream was excellent. 

Our server (Stephani) was very friendly and helpful.

You can sit almost anywhere and see at least one TV, as they are everywhere.  
Young, friendly good-looking staff.
Reasonable prices, good food, good service.

Yay!
author: Ramon V.

description:
Great place for pre and post game drinks. This place can get packed quickly, but always a good time.

Fully stocked bar for the most part and good service.

The only thing to worry about is the free for all to find a table. :-/
author: Marc M.

description:
Good rotating beer selection and awesome staff

Baseball season is back!!

I come here more than anywhere else, especially during baseball season.  I always stop here and get a beer (or way more) to bring into the game.  That's right, bring it into the game.  You are retarded if you don't do this.  Their prices alone are worth it plus with a much wider selection of beers you can't go wrong!  Also, I often come here just to watch but end up getting free tickets (3 times this season). I love SF fans!! So generous.
author: Devynne H.

description:
The only thing this place has going for it is it's proximity to the ballpark. Period.

The waiter was new and couldn't remember our orders but didn't write them down. We ordered one order of wings but got two. Out of a bunch of beers so the manager came over to offer alternatives but wasn't concerned with making sure our order was right. Our food came out hugely staggered and most of it was lukewarm to cold and one order was completely forgotten.

If you're a girl and not showing massive amounts of cleavage, the bartenders will ignore you.
author: Christine K.

description:
I haven't eaten here since the revamp, but I have had many a drink, and its a fun place to go. 

My friend and I watched game 6 of the NLCS here, landing possibly the last two decent spots to stand and watch the game. The drinks were pretty reasonable, and the atmosphere couldn't be beat when Uribe hit the HR that sent us on our way... 

Still one of the most fun nights I've ever had in a bar - great spot for pre-game before going to watch the Giants or to watch a game there! I will have to try the food soon...
author: Sam A.

description: If you're lookin for pre-game bar you're wasting your time here.  21st Amendment is just a few blocks up 2nd street and their beer and food are much much much better!
author: Steve C.

description:
I hate writing negative reviews, and make it a point not to, but this place could be fantastic with a minor service overhaul (more bartenders), so hence why I'm posting.  Because honestly Public House, this is just getting silly.  Any time I come here before a game, I talk this place up and tell my friends how good the beer selection is, and how you can bring them into the park.  And every time, we wait in a 15 minute line at the FRONT of the bar, watching rude, understaffed bartenders pass us by again and again.

Last night was the worst.  A group of girls near us had a very complicated order, and a female bartender was rude to the point of actually rolling her eyes and saying "Really??" in a sarcastic tone when they said they wanted one more drink.  The girls were understandably upset, since you know, they were being berated for ordering drinks at a freaking bar, and were talking poorly about the bartender after they received their order.  A man at the bar jokingly pointed to the girls, who were standing right behind us by this point, and said to the bartender, "they don't like you too much", at which point she got confused about who he was pointing too, turned to me and my girlfriend (who is all of 5'1", for the record) and started getting in our face about "well well then, what can I get for the people who don't like me?"  We were so pissed at this rudeness (after waiting 15 minutes to order, mind you) that we just each took two beers to go in plastic cups...we had planned on staying, since there was an hour before the game, but were so turned off by how rude and slow all the bartenders were.

I have never not been here right before a game, so no idea what the service is like otherwise, but honestly, if they are going to have the amount of bars they have, they really need to have more bartenders working before home games.  For how cheesy Pedro's Cantina can be, at least they can efficiently work a similarly huge crowd at a large bar.

2 stars only because the beer list is fantastic and extensive, and by bringing in two beers each through the private entrance, it's silly not to get a better, bigger, and cheaper beer (or two) here first than to deal with overpriced domestics in the actual park.  But putting up with the slow, rude, and disinterested service is becoming a bit of a chore.
author: James S.

description: Best beer bar around, attached to the park, good service, great selection
author: Michael B.

description:
When you wanna yell and scream for the Giants without being in the confines of your home all dressed up with no ticket.

Or...you  have standing room only and you forgot that you had run earlier that morning and were sore and desperate for a seat to watch the game. So we went here.

Found a spot right near the flat screens. Dodger game to boo on the left and the Giants game on the right. Nice. Beer was good and it felt nice being around so much Orange and Black.
author: Stephanie H.

description:
Okay, i came here during Beer Week a couple times, but it's still the baseball off-season, so i must bless the fact that i didn't have to experience a giant (HA!) crowd of people. I can see how it would get crowded though.

The bartenders were nice, and one of the nights i came they offered complimentary bar bites (pretzel balls, deep fried mac and cheese, bacon croissants) and they were pretty tasty. The second night i was here, my friends and i didn't have much trouble getting beers quickly, we even sat down at a table with no trouble, and the place was kind of busy. The food continued to be finger-ling-ling good, but when things are deep fried, how could you go wrong?

Also managed to watch my hockey games with no trouble at all. I probably wouldn't come back during baseball season (not a fan), but this place wasn't bad at all!
author: Phuong M.

description: Nice place to eat if you are about to go to the Gaints game. Nice drinks & food. Expensive but worth it
author: Danny F.

description:
Come on people with the less than three stars! This place is at the ballpark so you have to expect a large crowd pre and post game. The solution.. get there a little early or leave the ballpark before the end of the game, because THIS PLACE IS AWESOME!

I'm a regular and yes, when it does get busy, it takes longer to get service, but what place in SF isn't like that when there are tons of people. Security guys are awesome and the service is A+.

I frequent this place and have had almost everything on the menu and I have to give props to Tracey Desjardins for creating an awesome pub menu that pairs well with the beer selection or specialty cocktails.

Highlights for me.. mijita margarita, raspberry lemonade.. Food: Mini corn dogs, sweet potato fries, fish and chips and the grilled chicken california cobb sandwich.

If you have time to spare before or after a game or even on a non day game, check out Public House, talk to the employees, order a beer and sit back and relax to watch some sports and you'll realize just how special and fun this place can be! CHEERS!!
author: Michelle H.

description: I came here recently after the Giants Race so it was very packed. It took us a while to find a table as its a no host restaurant and you are required to seat yourself. I was with a party of 8 and half of us order breakfast while the other half ordered lunch. The breakfast people all got there food about 10 minutes before the lunch people which was a little odd as usually they wait but maybe because it was eggs it was quicker to make. I ordered the Quevos Rancheros which the waiter highly recommended I was sadly disappointed. Can't believe I paid so much for 2 scrambled eggs on a crispy tortilla with cold beans. So not worth, the money or time. Oh and the waiter barely came to check on us as the place was so busy but they should be properly staffed. Just because of its proximity to the ball park I might just give this place another chance but no breakfast this time.
author: Sunny S.

description:
My enthusiasm for Public House is related directly to their televisions. They're everywhere, showing a wide variety of events, and of high quality! SF's relative weakness in the sports bar category is a factor too. For a city of this size and stature, we could use more good sports bars. 

This is also a burger review since I'm reaching the last cohort of good dedicated burger places in SF. Specifically the Public House burger will not disappoint! It's served w bacon, cheddar and avocado (well guacomole on mine) plus fresh, crisp standard toppings. Four jars of condiments provided in advance of the plate itself. The patty was a good inch high and quite juicy. Perfect for flavoring fries in my personal steak frites fashion! They were whole-cut with skin on either en my favorite. Unfortunately they didn't taste as good as the burger because some thicker ones tasted as if they'd been fried frozen. 

Regardless I absolutely devoured the burger, less than 90 minutes after eating another entree, the chiliquenos plate. (That's a formal way of saying Frito pie.)

The service has never met the levels set by the food or beer however. I've never visited on the day of a Giants game, home or away, though this last visit (NFL playoffs) finally revealed the restaurant with most tables filled.

Our server was quick to welcome my late self to the couple I'd invited there (yes, very rude of me) and he offered the menus plus his food recommendations. Once he came back for my order though, the mistakes began: forgot my water and then forgot my silverware and napkin twice. On that note the silverware and napkin never arrived ahead of the food during my two previous visits. Not even simultaneously. At least they're of high quality! Getting a towel instead of a napkin feels more appropriate for pub food, even of the high-end variety.

So go to Public House for a very good sports bar experience and high-end pub food. Just don't expect too much from the service.
author: Mike H.

description:
1. The Public House Burger is the best burger I've had in SF.
2. Menu selection is dissapointing.
3. Great environment - beautiful restaurant and bar; lots of TV's for sports!

Bottom Line: I've been to Public House several times and I'll keep going there when I want a great burger.
author: John W.

description:
Arrived at 10am before the Giants vs. Cubs game. Wanted to get a bite to eat before going into the ballpark. Found a table easily and the server came up right away. We ordered but had to wait a while for our drinks. We had our 2 boys with us and they both ordered waffles. I ordered the huevos rancheros and my husband ordered a burger. The food came quickly, which was nice and the server was pleasant enough. The beans that came with the huevos ranchers were COLD. Yuck! The burger was decent and the waffles looked okay. 

Here is where the one star comes in. I went in to use the restroom and 2 of the stalls i visited had no seat covers. The bathroom seemed a bit of a mess and being that they JUSt opened, you figure that it should be clean. Walking out of the restroom, I bumped into the manager and nicely told her that 2 stalls needed attention. Allison, the manager on duty, was SO RUDE! In a really rude voice, she said,"Thank you for telling me." Then immediately looked away. It was not what she said, it was the attitude in which she said it.  Unbelievable! 

Then to add to the negative bathroom experience, after we left, one of the kids barfed up the waffle. Nice.  Felt perfectly fine afterwards and we enjoyed the Giants game, despite the 2-1 loss.
author: Doc H.

description: It's a sports bar right next to the Giants ballpark. What else is needed to be said? It gets pretty crowded on a game day. They have happy hour 4-6pm on weekdays. The Ballast Point Piper Down is on the HH list and it's pretty sweet. The HH food menu is pretty sizable, which includes wings, mini corn dogs, sweet fries, nachos, regular fries.
author: Foo L.

description:
We ate at the Public House on the day of the Giants home opener.  It was extremely crowded but managed to snag a table to order lunch.
Ordered the Little Gem Ceasar Salad with Tuna Confit.  It was a wonderful combination of flavors.  The dressing was the "right amount" over the fresh lettuce and chunks of tuna.  It was a refreshing combination.  The fish and chips were cooked perfectly and arrived hot.  A must for fish and chips.
The staff was very courteous, surprisingly for such a busy day.  It was nice alternative to eating stadium food in the stands.
author: Patricia R.

description:
We went to Public House after a Quakes game at AT&T. Since it was late afternoon, we got in early and had primarily appetizers and drinks. My wife and our friend has Irish coffee and wine. My wife really enjoyed her Irish coffee. However, it was the beer that floored me. I like trying new beers and the waiter steered me to two:

Stone Double Bastard 2010
Ballast Point Victory at Sea

Seriously, two of the best beers that I have ever had! There were so many beers that I wanted to try. This place is worth it just for the beer! Really enjoyed just sitting and watching college basketball and talking. Started to get crowded around 7:00pm (it was a Saturday night). Waiter was cool and never pushed us to leave.

As far as the appertizers, Chorizo & Jalapeno Fritters, Mijita Nachos, Poblanos, Beans, Salsa, Guacamole and onion rings. All were good. Wife and kids loved the nachos, and I liked the fritters. 

Since I have only been once, I give them a four, but I would seriously go back anytime for just the beer.
author: John R.

description:
So if you know me at all, you know of my hatred for the Giants. NOT a fan. At all. So when they're in the NLCS in Philadelphia, why not go directly into the heart of prick Giants fan-land for a few drinks??

A buddy of mine is a big Giants fan and chose this place for our Saturday evening night out. I'm a huge beer fan and I have a great deal of admiration for places that go out of their way to cater to the beer crowd that wants nothing to do with Bud Lite and Pabst Blue Ribbon. They have a great selection of beer on tap including a couple of cask ales to choose from. There's also a decent selection of Belgian ales in the bottle if that's your thing. I also found the dual bars pretty cool, cocktails on one side, beer on the other. 

My two companions and I split an order of nachos and fish and chips. The fish and chips were average, the fish at least seemed fresh and had a good batter. The nachos were tasty and came on a fried tortilla thing that made for a good presentation.

Despite my hatred of the Giants, I must say, the energy in the place was electric. These fans were cheering every pitch, every hit, every close-up of Lincecum's face and were on the edge of their seats for the entire game. If you're a Giants fan and you appreciate good beer, I know you'll love this place. 

Bleh! I don't want to see the color orange for at least a month...
author: Nate R.

description: Pub food and good beer. Can't ask for anything better really. Service can get slow because it's a large place and the bathrooms are also pretty small. But the beer! Come here for the beer! It can get super busy before games so good luck finding a seat.
author: Julianna M.

description: If you're really, really nice and it's a slow day (meaning, there isn't a Giants game), ask one of the bartenders for a shot of bourbon and a slice of bacon. You can thank me later.
author: Ruggy J.

description: I am trying to reign this review in so that it does not come off as overly gushing. But I love this place. Everything about it. Location--INSIDE AT&T park. The only other place better to watch a Giants game is inside the stadium, a few short feet away!  The Drinks. So many choices! A bear menu that rotates quite often and a staff that will let you try things to get your perfect beer.  The Food, some of the best Nachos I have ever had. A great burger a wonderful chicken sandwich. Homemade chips, great fries... oh its all so good. Lastly they have about 15 or so huge TV's and if you want to watch something else on one of them they will try and make it happen. Top to bottom my favorite sports bar ever. EVER
author: douglas B.

description: Unless you just want to drink (and I know that's why it is a sports bar) don't go for good food.  We went at 5 on Saturday and waited about 10 minutes for a seat.  Once we found a seat ordered fairly quickly and about 20 minutes later they came to tell us they had no fish (we had ordered 2 fish and chips dinner) re-ordered and asked for fries in the meantime 'cause we were starving...about 10 minutes later the waiter brought us chips in a basket (tasted stale) because the fries were taking awhile.  Got the fries and they were pieces of fries with an occassional full fry.  Nachos were cold with about 15 beans hidden in the middle of the pile of chips under cold cheese.  Did not bother to send back ... ate a few of them and had to run but definitely would not recommend for food.
author: Kelly M.

description: This is a good place to watch NFL games on Sundays.  There's sufficient seating, friendly service, and decent food and drinks.
author: Neill T.

description:
Great weeknight venue for beers after work. I mention this because apparently it can be swamped on the weekend (what a surprise given their sports focus). I popped in on a Thursday night just before 1900 to meet with some friends. Only 1 or 2 tables left for the 6 of us. The big reason was that there was a SF beer week event in their large tabled area. A good 30 people enjoying tastings of a wide variety of beers. No matter, both our groups had a great time!

They have a good selection of various drafts and bottles and serve food as well. I was somewhat confused on what the actual beer menu was - there's beer and food listed on the place mats and a separate 2 page sheet listing a variety of beers. I probably would have preferred to order from the 2 pages (more choices), however the server noted that it was very likely out of date. Dang.

There were other groups, also meeting to discuss/do some afterwork business by the looks of it and the bars were pretty full for those just seeking an after-work drink. There are TV's on most walls, though given how spacious Public House is, some of them may be too far away for comfortable viewing.

The downside is really their location - you have to work in the area or be willing to MUNI in (it took me 40 minutes from Rockridge BART + N Line to get there during rush hour though so not a big deal. N line or 30 bus comes relatively frequently to get you back up to BART as your schedule dictates).
author: Kevin M.

description:
I'm not sure why people look at me crazy when I announce from my seat " I'm headed to Public House." 

Hmm. $9 beer close to the seats OR $6 Racer IPA here ( and many other quality drafts to choose from)  that I can bring back to my seat. 

You all graduated jr high, I'm sure you can make the right choice. 

I really like the staff here. She's cool, he's cool, and the cocktail server is nice but I would've liked to order some food to celebrate the Giants beating the Cubs. I guess they don't serve food after the game. 

Beware of the weak, long line that forms to enter before games.
author: Taj A.

description: Over a dozen beers, quick service, great place to be before a game. The beers lacked descriptions (besides names), but my smart phone was able to figure it out for me after a search. They didn't have any Red Ales, at least that night. Might stop by next time, much better deal than in the park!
author: Matthew W.

description:
5 stars for the ground sirlion sliders

sampled two things here plus some shots haha

the mini reuben sandwich - thin sliced pastrami on a house made thousand island dressing with sauerkraut and swiss cheese with some triangle wedged bread, would pass on these

the ground sirlion beef with white cheddar sliders - excellent on every bite, juicy, flavorful, filling, I had about 6 and that was all I needed

shots at the bar when catching up with old friends shots is a good way to catch up. the bartender poured and we devoured, good spot for drinks during, before or after a game.

food ***** for the beef sliders for the reuben definite pass for me
price fixed menu fixed price
service ***** excellent
ambiance **** very large restaurant / sports bar definitely a place to visit during a game if not when they Giants play away from home.
author: Clarence A.

description:
Came here on a quiet Thursday night to catch up over drinks with a friend. We both commute from the southbay, so we were looking for a good place for drinks in SOMA. What a perfect place! 

The beer selection is fantastic. The bartender was really nice and gave me an excellent recommendation(the Ommegang BPA!) after listening to what I like. He even let me try a little bit first. The food is also tasty, though priced on the higher side (we are in SOMA after all).

Overall, an excellent choice for casual, weekday drinks near Caltrain.
author: Vickie C.

description: Don't come here unless you're starving or you're just going to have ONE DRINK. Over priced and not worth it.
author: JaxAlani W.

description:
HH only

Was here yesterday before the game started, so i really can't review the food and what not... 

it was crowded due to the game, but getting a drink wasn't a problem... maybe because i'm a girl i can wiggle my way to the front of the bar?  i thought their beer selection was just ok... wasn't like they had 20 beers on tap or anything.  the atmosphere is great for a ball game and for nice weather... so yesterday was perfect to hang out here... get the excitment from the crowd before the game... and also enjoy the nice weather at their outdoor seating area... 

but u know what's the best part about public house before the game?  their beers are half the price of ball park beers... so you can afford to get toasty before hand without burning a hole in your wallet!! plus, they have their own ball park entry... so that's a bonus!
author: Kelly H.

description:
Pros: The beer selection here is fantastic. Amazing location in AT&T Park. Dozens of TV's make it a great a spot to watch sporting events. I've only had apps here. The buffalo wings and nachos were better than what you would find at comparable places. 

Cons:  They sometimes don't have every beer offered on the menu. Weekday hours are limited. They open late and close early.
author: Chris M.

description:
At first I thought a two star seemed really low for the overall experience... but honestly, the "Meh. I've experienced better" is the way I would describe Public House.  

Plus side: food was decent, certainly agree with the thumbs up on the beer selection, lots of TV and our sever was actually very pleasant.  

Unfortunately, what I will remember most is the 'tude from the bartender when I was looking out for someone I was with on the alcohol intake.    The bartender was debating with me on cutting someone off.  Really?  Is the additional $12 glass of beer worth that much to you?  I actually said to him, shouldn't you be nice to customers?  He told me I may have been a customer at my table, but I wasn't a customer at the bar.  WOW.  Classy.  All so a person could have 1 more $12 drink.  What a winner.  

So here we are at the end of the day... I gave it a chance... so cheers to my last round @ Public House... thanks for the memories... 

If you're looking for a sports bar in the area, Pete's Tavern is right across the street... and they definitely have a more positive, chill vibe and will remain my regular place to catch games in the south beach area.
author: Aileen C.

description:
Went here for the Giants game (which took us to the championship proceeded buy us winning that '10). Bar was completely packed, couldn't get a drink or food order without having to reiterate 'em. Crowd was expected though since we all know our SF patrons when it comes to baseball and the Giants.

 Nachos were absolutely delicious. Forgot which ice cream Ian ordered that night but it was salted caramel? And it was pretty good as well. Despite the crowd and the hectic scene we still managed to get our food and our drinks within 10 minutes. 

Completely packed and had a single file line beginning to wrap around the place BUT still managed to get in without dealing with that line? Whaat?

Interesting bar/restaurant and there's a door that leads to the dug out which is pretty interesting. Had a great time hugging, high-fiving, dancing and screaming with random SF patrons in the bar. It was the first time where I didn't mind getting kissed on the cheek by a drunk, happy go-er. Nice ambiance and great staff. Bartender was very detailed with any questions on the menu as well. From what I remember..they also had coat racks mantled against the walls next to the dining area...random note.
author: Kat L.

description: Friendly service, lots of Chenin Blanc, nice place to hang out for sunday football w my bf :)
author: Rachel D.

description:
Came here post-game / post-Pete's Tavern with a group of ladies to chow down on some fried baseball food.  She steps up. She hits. She scores. 

Mini Corn Dogs = Base Hit.

Jalapeno Poppers = Home Run.

Deviled Eggs = Grand Slam (i'm a little ghetto for my deviled eggs / hot & spicy deliciousness).

Martinis. Martinis. Martinis.
author: Nicole Rynee B.

description:
Went here for Game 4 of the World Series..GO GIANTS!!

It was amazing being able to celebrate with so many Giants fans and being at PH was the closest to the park w/o being inside. You definitely cannot beat the ambiance, with a buttload of TVs surrounding you, as well as great fans.

Food although was very disappointing with a very small menu (altho it was a special basebal menu), very high prices for even SMALLER portions. Food also tasted mediocre which was sadly surprising. Beer menu was extensive altho pricy as well. (Watch out for the different sizes..some are only 10oz!)

I would definitely go back for Giants games but may just drink and not eat.
author: Joe C.

description:
Nice place to get together with friends to watch the game on their nice tv screens and have a drink. They also have food on their menu but we already ate when we got here. 

We did order some drinks and desserts. They carry ice cream from one of the popular ice cream shops in SF (Humphrey B?). We had the Tahitian vanilla and the butterscotch pudding (which was yummy but super creamy and thick).

It's in my hood so prolly will be back again.
author: Cynthia C.

description: Fun place to meet after the game and wait for the traffic to die down.  God drinks and if you can find a place to sit or be comfortable then I would suggest planting roots for while.  Great people watching.
author: Eli B.

description:
Great pre-gaming spot! AT&T Park should have thought of having a sports pub like this years ago. The bar area at ACME was always crammed with people, and did anyone really even eat there? I certainly didn't.

They offer 24 beers on tap and 24 bottled beers... paying homage to Willie Mays? The food menu offers yummy gourmet ballpark food which is a great alternative to what they offer inside the park. 

The place certainly does get packed before a Giants game, but you easily save $3/beer and the variety is totally worth it.

Well played, Public House. Well played.
author: Connie C.

description:
Freshly cut grass, shouts of "Program!", dogs grilling and the sun setting behind the bay: Opening Night.

With the orange sky as the backdrop, we headed to the Public House a few hours before the game to dig into some brews and enjoy the excitement of the new ball season.

The space is vast, with high ceilings, and a long rock bar with wide windows. Flat screens adorn the walls and for a sports fan, submerging you in highlights and top tens. 

The beer selection is vast, and the group delighted in checking off as many as possible. There are 2 bars, with one serving the usual on tap, while the other has a list of micro brews. It's hard to not find something you're completely content with.

The menu plays upon traditional ball park items. With Mijita adjoined to the Public House, we were able to tap into their kitchen and went with the nachos which were the only disappointing aspect of the venue. Served on a toasted quesadilla, they lacked the items to identify it as a dish.

Service was stellar, upbeat, and our crew had a blast. 

Park yourself here before a ball game and you'll enter the stadium primed to enjoy the game. No doubt.
author: Mike K.

description:
Overcrowded buttttttttttttt...I haven't tried anything other than the beers before a Giants Game.

Of course its going to be crowded...but I didn't think it was anything special. The only thing I really enjoyed was the open space, high ceilings and clean look. 

Other than that.....there's no reason I would go back...really, I don't see the appeal other than the proximity to the ballpark. 

Downgrade :(
author: Rachel Z.

description:
It's not very often that I walk out on a place, but it happened today.

We went to this place with the intent of eating a bit of lunch, and possibly a Friday beer or two. Oh, yeah...and I think there's some soccer thing going on, too.

This place and a small taqueria are apparently owned by the same guy, and they're almost indistinguishable from each other. What appeared to be the spot where the host would normally stand, had nobody there. Huh. So we wander in. Lots of tables available. So we grab one.

Waiters wander by. Attempts to get their attention fail. "Excuse me....hello....hi, could you tell me..."  No dice. These guys were like zombies, far more interested in the TV screens than in the customers. When one of us finally gets up and stands directly in front of a waiter, the waiter finally says something about food not being served until 4 PM.

The napkins and salt & pepper shakers on each table are apparently just decor during lunchtime.

3 other groups of people are in the same boat that we are, and are having just as much luck getting staff attention as us. OK, so it's not my clothes that are the problem.

So we get up, and wander into the taqueria. We see another guy standing behind one of the counters, but he's doing the same turkey-in-the-rain thing that all the other staff were doing. "Hi....do you have any menus?"

So he hands us each a slip of paper. The items on this "menu" qualify at best as appetizers, not as any sort of a meal. After being ignored when we walked in, spending about 10 minutes to get the attention of a waiter only to find that we're in a food-free zone, and now a non-menu from which to select lunch....that's it. Let's just go some place else.

And for the kicker, as we walk out the door, I've still got my "menu" in my hand. I don't want it and not knowing where else to put it, I set it on a counter near the door, and I hear a staff member behind me say, "excuse me...those don't belong there." In the tone of voice you might use with a 5-year-old. 

Oh, you did NOT just say that.

"Excuse me?", I ask, not believing what my ears just told me. And steam's shooting out of them by this point.

"They belong over there," he says, pointing to a stack of them on a different counter. He's a bit nicer this time: he sounds like he's talking to a 6-year-old. Maybe even 6 and a half.

Well, I certainly want to make him happy. "Oh, okay" I say with a gentle smile. I crumple it up, and chuck it in the trash can.

I know it's the World Cup, and yes: this is a sports bar. It's probably a good thing to hire staff who at least appreciate athletics. But newsflash, kids: you are there to WORK. *I* am the customer, not you. 

Do your god damn jobs first, and watch the game second.

To summarize the low points:

- Not having greeters at the door? Bad. 
- Waiters who ignore the clientele? Really bad.
- Scolding a customer for not putting a piece of paper in its "correct" spot? That's just flat-out stupid.

I'll not be returning to either place.
author: Tim B.

description: Haven't had a meal at the Public House yet, but have definitely enjoyed drinks before, after (and even during!) Giants games.  Excellent selection of IPAs and well-stocked bar.  Bartenders are friendly even when slammed before a game, and I have watched servers efficiently negotiate a very crowded bar floor with pub snacks and dinner orders with ease.  I'd recommend the Public House anytime as a meeting place whether you're in town for a game or not.  I'll definitely go back and look forward to trying the food.
author: Aneesh B.

description:
I learned about the opening of Public House during the Giants Fanfest in February.  Even though I was one of the few people who actually liked ACME Chophouse, I would agree that ACME was perhaps the wrong choice for a ballpark restaurant.  As a Giants season ticketholder, I was really looking forward to something new, and I was excited about the limitless possibilities Public House.  

I've been here 3 times now (once before a preseason game, once during a lengthy rain delay and once before a regular season game) and I am still waiting for Public House to impress me.  I am sure they are still working out the kinks, but do they really have to do it at the expense of their customers?

The restaurant undoubtedly has potential.  The flat screens on the walls are tuned to various sports channels, although I've had a very hard time trying to track someone down to change the channel to something actually worth watching.  "What Yankees game?  Is it on right NOW?"  I was asked during TBS Sunday Morning game.  I thought you guys were running a sports bar...

On our first visit my friend and I noticed that the restaurant was grossly overstaffed.  The waitstaff were literally standing around, waiting to snatch a plate off the table.  Not only did I feel rushed, but I was afraid they were going to rip my arm off.  Well, not really.  On my subsequent visits, I noticed that they were grossly understaffed.  We had a hard time getting anyone's attention.  So much for "just enough," eh?

I also fail to understand their positioning.  If they want people to think of this place as an upscale organic eatery with a bar, why do the waiters have a sassy, almost rude, attitude like one would expect at a bar?  The "bouncer" and then the waiter almost yelled at us for bringing a Starbucks coffee cup to the restaurant.  Umm, do you think I am not going to order anything else?  You need to relax and respect your customers.

As far as the food goes, everything here is really, really small.  An order of sliders isn't big enough to share, and neither is an order of deviled eggs.  Actually, the salads are decent sized, so you could probably split those with your partner in crime.

The sandwiches and hotdogs here are much smaller than what you pay for, but at least they taste better than the crap you'll get inside.  The cheesesteak is delicious and not overly greasy.  All their sandwiches have a unique, "designer" look and taste, so there's that.  I love the Secret Breakfast ice cream they serve, which seems like a steal at $2.  Yes, you guessed it, it's small, too, but it's all the ice cream I can handle.

I think Public House has a lot of potential.  If they try to control the crowds, it would be a fantastic spot to watch sporting events while waiting for the Giants game to start.  I am sick and tired of going to Zeke's, and I was ready for something better.  Public House could be that.  They just need to turn some of the tables towards the TVs on the walls and maybe throw in an extra slider every once in a while.  If you are forced to pay $8 for two bite size burgers, you might as well be "surprised" by a third one on the house.  Just sayin'.
author: Yan G.

description: Packed on game days. Little known secret: you can buy drinks "to go" before a game and enter the stadium from within the bar. They don't have give-aways at that entrance tho if you're trying to get the Hector Sanchez bobblehead. They also have a nice side bar with some unique microbrews: think Russian River, the Bruery, belgian style beers. Get your drinks to go and go giants!
author: J S.

description:
Went here Saturday after fan fest, 2/5/11. Had 2 kids with me; we were hot, thirsty & very hungry.  Took a while for waitress to acknowledge us, ok busy day.  Took our drink order only brought mixed drink had to wait for kids waters.  Took food order; mac& cheese, nachos.  Nachos soggy & flavorless.  Mac&cheese had too many different types of cheeses for kids taste.

Waitress never came back to ask us how things were, never refilled waters, had flag another waitress down.  Told her we were very unhappy with food, she gave us attitude and said looks like you ate it.  Well yeah we were starving, had 6-7 bites of soggy nachos, 4-5 bites of mac&cheese.  

Finally our waitress came back with attitude and said "I heard you didn't like your food; here's your tab minus the food."

What a waste of time.  We left hungry, a little less thirsty but feeling like we left the little shop of horrors.

Owners;  you should have some kid friendly items on your menu, are you freakin kidding me? Ever heard of chicken strips & fries?  Chili cheese fries, sliders.  You are at a baseball park!

When there's something going on at the park have more wait staff on the floor.  Hire people friendly staff.

Learn how to make nachos that aren't soggy.

We will never be back.

If only this place was The Yardhouse!
author: Julie B.

description:
If you are looking for a place to watch Giants games, it doesn't get much better than this. As sports bars go, this is about as good as I've seen. Walls of kegs, flat screens everywhere you look, about 2 million beers on tap...what more could you want. 

Before and after the game it gets extremely packed, with very little chance of getting a table. The layout, with two bars creating almost a funnel near the entrance, isn't the best for traffic flow. That aside, there is nothing better then cheering for the Giants with 200 other people all packed in tight. 

The beer selection here is outstanding. They have beers that I've never sen on tap anywhere! For example, North Coast Brewing Co Rasputin, a beer that will put hair on your chest. They also know how to pour Guiness here. I always use that as a judge of the bar. Inside the park they will ruin your $8 Guiness with an awful pour, letting the specialized spigot submerge in the beer like they are trying to drown it. At the Public House, they start with the proper angle, fill it up 3/4, let it sit (very agonizing) and then top it off, resulting in the perfect pour.
author: Scott C.

description:
What ever happened to the good old days of serving beer on tap in an ice cold glass? 
My first choice of beer was unavailable, wow! I settled for Allagash white for starters and washed that down with Anchor Liberty. Two thumbs up for both.
The food selection was very limited for football Sunday, so I went with the daily grind burger. This was no ordinary burger, damn it was good. White Cheddar, Avocado, bacon, house ground beef, need I say more... Oh yeah, toasted bun. The fries looked nice but too heavy with salt. If Niners didn't make my BP go up the fries sure did the trick.     
The amount of HD tv's was amazing. I was like a kid in the candy store. All I gots to say is man heaven. 
Will I go back? Hell Yeah!
author: Lou G.

description:
Came here to watch Heat vs Mavs in the finals with B. Luckily it wasn't packed, and we sat ourselves at a high table and were promptly asked for drink orders. B was so engrossed in the game though, that he didn't realize that we hadn't placed food orders, so we flagged down our waitress and put in orders for a Reuben sandwich and Mac n Cheese. 

Overall everything was a little pricey (for next to the ballpark, what else can you expect?) for a-okay food. The Mac n cheese WAS a ramekin full of delicousness, but go to Public House for the atmosphere and go with good friends to get a drink and hash out a game - the food is just a side thing to your experience.
author: Julia C.

description:
Great food.  
Great ambiance.
And Giants around the corner.  

Need I say more?

Personal favorite menu item -- the chicken sandwich.  Yum!
author: Joanna S.

description:
Sitting with friends before the big game, enjoying some brewskies, pretty pink cocktails, and fancy nachos resting on a tortilla bed, I was a happy woman. I turn and look over my shoulder towards the ball park and am an even happier woman knowing that I can waltz through an entrance to the game in the restaurant itself, cheaper beverage in hand. 

At a closer look, though, there are some cracks in this Public House. The nachos were fancy but skimpy. The pretty pink cocktail didn't taste entirely pretty and the brewskie (watermellon wheat) was probably not the best choice. At a more obvious glance you could see our server and the store manager laboriously attempt to run our card while their credit device was broken which took much longer than we would have liked.

All-in-all, this is a great spot to start out the drinking festivities before you hit the park. The drinks are cheaper (at least by a little bit) than if you were to buy them in the park and the food is good. 

P.S. Ryan the server is awesome - make sure to give him a hefty tip.
author: Julia N.

description: I came here on a monday night game against the Phillies. This place was packed and there was barely any walking room. Goodluck trying to get service if you didnt come super early. I ended going to the grab and go bar near the side entrance to the stadium (I suggest you go through this way to cut through the line at the main entrance). Service was quick and there was no line. Beers will run about $7 for a 16oz and a couple more for the 22oz, not many good options though. Plenty of televisions showing multiple games with a decent amount of seating. If not here, then you can stroll over the Mijita, but I doubt there'll be any over there. I think the seating is pretty much take what's open, so it's always a mad dash like musical chairs. There's a outside patio which additional seating and more standing room if you are desperate. Try to avoid if possible on home games.
author: Phan H.

description: A nice place to catch a sport game on tv. They have plenty of beers on tap to choose from. During SF Giants home games, it gets pretty packed here, so arrive early if you want a seat and have some food and brews before the game. If you have tickets to the SF Giants game, they have an entrance to the park here. If you purchased a drink from here, they will let you take it into the park. You just have to transfer it into a plastic cup. When it gets close to game time, the line to get into the park is very slow.
author: Frances V.

description:
The service at Public House was sooooo disappointing. My family and I went to get our picture taken with the World Series trophy (GO GIANTS!) and since I'd been wanting to check this place out for quite some time, we'd figured it'd be a great opportunity to stop in for dinner after the photo sesh. Sure enough we came along and sat at one of the many empty tables- front and center, close to the bar. It was a Wednesday night and pretty slow. Not ONCE were we greeted by any of the wait staff, or offered menus, drinks...nothing. 

I noticed that none of the staff ever cracked a smile so it got me to thinking that maybe the worker morale at the restaurant is really low- or maybe I just caught everyone on their off day? Obviously nobody was motivated to greet us or take our order, and we made it pretty clear that we were settled in and waiting to be helped. I'm a really patient person but once the 25 minute marker hit and we still hadn't been greeted, we eventually packed up and went to MoMo's. I'm super bummed because I didn't get to try any of the food or beer :(

I don't mean to judge this place so harshly on one really bad experience, but I think it'll take a while for me to want to go back there. I hope no one else has the same first experience we did.
author: Katie S.

description: Ventured to public house on a Giants away day.  Plenty of seats available and a good feel inside, casual and plenty o tv's to watch various sports.  The beer selection is great and wait staff was helpful in recommending a few to us.  The food was okay and prices reasonable.  I had the cuban sandwich which i always like to order, but always thinks needs a little something else to go with it.  i added mustard.  Definitely need to go back to try more on the menu and more of the beer selection.
author: Susan Z.

description: Good pre-game spot. Drinks are cheaper than ballpark prices AND you can carry your drinks into the ballpark if purchased in this establishment. The only con is that it gets packed quickly, so finding a seat can be very hard.
author: Amy L.

description:
The reason for the 4 stars - the service. The managers, waitstaff, food runners, and bussers were amazing. Service was efficient, friendly, and attentive without being overwhelming. I can't recall the last time I experienced such amazing service. The service alone would bring me back to this restaurant. 

The food... Oh the food... I would give it MAYBE 3 stars. That's a very strong maybe...

My friend ordered the beer steamed mussels with sour ale, fennel and grilled bread. Sadly it smelled better than it tasted. The broth, if you can call it that, tasted like watered down soup. There was absolutely no flavor in the broth, which is a shame because when you order mussels, the best part is sopping up the broth with the bread! Also, my friend felt like she could fend off vampires with the amount of garlic she ate in her dish. 

I had the grilled chicken breast, avocado, bacon and blue cheese sandwich. They should say the sandwich comes with arugula as well since some people aren't fans of that green. I actually loved the combination. The flavors blended very well together. I do wish there wasn't so much bread (I'm guessing a ciabatta roll...) and the chicken breast was a bit thicker (although it was incredibly flavorful). The description on the menu should say the sandwich comes with chips, which were a bit on the greasy side. 

We also ordered french fries that were unevenly salted. They're standard fries so not much else to comment on. 

I was surprised we were able to come in and grab a seat given it was 5:30 with the Giants playing in town, but shows that it's possible to grab a bite before the game! I liked how quick the kitchen worked - shows they know their customers and try to get them in and out the door for game time. 

Overall, for the price you pay, the food you receive, and the service you get, it's a pretty good option for a pregame meal. However, I probably wouldn't go here if I wasn't attending a game.
author: Kim C.

description:
my last experience at public house sucked.

ive been here several times for HH drinks at the bar, but got a table this time around because i was hungry and wanted to grab a bite while watching the games on tv...this was all around 430pm...

me and a friend finished a couple drinks and some grub...thats when the server started being a bit "pushy"...kept asking if we wanted the next drinks "to go" because that was an option...im sitting there watching the game...there's plenty of food on my table...2 new drinks...AND i had just ordered another dish as well....and she kept asking...drink, after drink, after drink...

i finally left...after ordering 6 appetizers and 5 drinks each because the freaking server made me feel guilty for sitting there watching the game while other people were looking to vulture our table...

not to mention she spilled water all over my friends pants when some other customer kind of nudged her....all she said was "sorry" and didnt even bring a napkin.

horrible service. stupid ass server. never again.




------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
after my review blast...the GM reached out to me...concerned about the crap service i had there...

needless to say...as a paying customer...regardless of my disgruntled self...im reasonable...and the fact that someone reached out to me and acknowledged my dissatisfaction with my experience there, speaks volumes.

thanks to the GM. if only all your team members cared like you do.
author: Kyu L.

description: So bummed.  Came and waited in line before the game, but by the time they opened all the tables were taken bc ppl had snuck through Mijita.  So irritated we waited in line for this.  Even tried to make reservations but was told they don't take any...several tables reserved.  They should have a better way to manage this!
author: H M.

description:
Went here yesterday before the exhibition game vs. the A's. We sat ourselves and our waitress came over shortly after.

I got the Grilled Cheese with caramelized onions, it was served with potato chips and it was all very good and tasty. My dad got the Fish and Chips... the french fries were super awesome! BUT his fish was old and disgusting, matter of fact he got FOOD POISONING FROM THIS FISH! Cool thanks Public House for giving my dad food poisoning (hence the total sarcasm)!

It sucks but you wont see me in here until the day you see pigs flyin'!
author: Caitlin M.

description:
I came here before a Giants game for the convenience.  The prices are on the high side as you would expect.  I ordered french toast ($10) that was yummy and delicate with an interesting combination of pistachios and Asian pears.  The serving size was small.  I was also able to sample a sandwich that was not particularly interesting.  There are lots of televisions showing all the sports you could possibly want to see.  Get here early if you don't want to wait long.  This place is packed before and after games.

The waiter informed me of the new policy to hold on to a credit card for the duration of the meal to prevent people skipping out on their checks.  I went along with it, but it made me uncomfortable, especially with how busy the place gets.  It would simply be too easy to misplace it or give it back to the wrong person.  It also feels wrong for the business to treat customers like thieves without just cause.  If you like receipt checkers at Walmart/Costco, I guess you will have no issue.  I recommend simply paying for your meal up front.

I'd come back if someone else wanted to eat here, but I don't think I'd choose it myself.  It's not particularly Giants-themed except for being part of the ballpark.  I'll be fine eating traditional ballpark fare.
author: M C.

description:
So much better than Mijitas next door.  Case in point: Public House was fairly full for a Wednesday night.  Mijitas, nearly empty.

Enjoyed the crab cake with aiole, beef sliders, bubbling hot mac & cheese, and a chicken sandwich (grilled with yummy figs for that something special).  Including a beer, this meal ran about $50.  Not cheap, but the food was good.  Don't know if it's $50 worth of good, but we'd still go back.
author: Denise M.

description:
HUGE FAN! What a great addition to the pre-game bars and eateries. I have to say, this is just what the ballpark needed. 

Came here before a friday night game around 5pm. We did have a hard time finding a table but persistence paid off and within 5 minutes of keeping an eagle eye out we got lucky and a group left. I think 4:30 would be the perfect time to get here. 

BEER TIP: I liked the large drink menu, although my first beer (21st Amendment Watermelon Wheat, my favorite!!) wasn't THAT cold. Ugh. But, my next couple were crisp and refreshing. My best guess is it was the draft beer vs. canned? Good to know. 

Food was good and greasy, perfect for before a ballgame. Nachos were my least favorite, while the pigs in a blanket were the best. The price was right too. Not too pricey for 4 people, ordering lots of food and drinks.
author: Natalie N.

description:
I'm no stranger to the bars around the ballpark, but for some reason I didn't notice that Acme House had been replaced until the end of May. Some friends and I bought tickets to the Giants Beerfest, being held prior to a Saturday evening game. We got into the "festival", had a few dixie cups filled with beer, and realized that we'd be spending most of our time standing in line if we decided to stay. We decided to leave and spend the two hours before the game somewhere else. 

We happened upon Public House and decided to check it out. The first thing I noticed - rows upon rows of glorious flat screen tv's hanging on the walls. Big, beautiful, clear screens showing every sporting event you'd ever want to see. Then I got up to the bar and noticed the huge selection of beer - and not just the standard Sierra Nevada, Anchor Steam, and Guiness. They had all kinds of options I had never heard of but immediately wanted to try. I got some kind of german beer that I can't pronounce or spell. My friend got some kind of watermelon cider (delicious with just a hint of watermelon). It got a little more crowded as it got closer to the game, but it was still comfortable. It also has a separate entrance to the ballpark, and YOU CAN TAKE YOUR DRINKS WITH YOU INTO THE STADIUM!! 

I've been back several times since. When I went to a Saturday game during the World Cup, Public House was the obvious choice for pre-game drinks.
author: Melinda M.

description:
I came here to watch the Lakers and Giants kick some ass (which they did) and eat a burger and enjoy some good brews. We started off with the delectable crab cakes. I've never had a crab cake before, so this probably doesn't mean too much, but it was the best crab cake I've ever had! :P

I also started off with the Racer IPA ($6) and then went with the Moylans Kilt Lifter Scotch Ale * 8% * $7 * Amazeballs!!! 

The bacon and guacamole burger met expectations and was just as good as the delicious appetizer and refreshing brews. This is supposedly a great place to come before/during/after a Giants home game, but I say it's great anytime!
author: Casi C.

description:
This place is awesome!

They have great beers on tap, including my new favorite Allagash White. The best part is that they will serve you the beer in a plastic cup. You can take your cup and walk across the restaurant to the turnstiles that lead directly into the ballpark. So if you're understanding what I'm saying...you can get a $6 glass of Allagash White and bring it into the park instead of paying $8 for a cup of Bud Light!

Life doesn't get much better than this. The only issue is that it gets really crowded on game days but then again, I''d be shocked if it didn't.

And I just read that there's a patio. I'm going to have to check that out on a non-game day so I can get a seat and enjoy some great beers outside.
author: Jackie G.

description: Packed as a mother but great crowd before a game!  Bartenders and security are cool.  I was thirsty and they gave me water.  All kinds of games going on on their flat panel TVs.  Thank you!
author: Dee H.

description: The food is good and the crowd is always fun and lively. Only draw back is it gets really packed and often when there's a big game there's only standing room.
author: T G.

description:
I came here during an away game to grab some beers and watch the Giants.  Happy Hour is great--they usually have $3 cask ales, food specials, and a couple of draft beers on sale.  The selection isn't enormous, but does a great job of featuring some hard to find local brews.  I loved the Marin Brewing Orange & Black; it was brewed for the World Series and, at least according to our waitress, is almost gone.

Service was casual and knowledgeable, perfect for a bar like Public House.  We got several excellent suggestions and nothing missed the mark.

Food was a low point.  Our table didn't have anything inedible, but nothing stood out.  As I sit trying to remember, I can only vaguely pick out mini-corndogs and jalapeno poppers.  On happy hour pricing (50% off), the bites were welcome to soak up the beer, but I couldn't see getting the same portions at full price.

I don't know if I would brave any gameday crowds to visit Public House, but for a relaxed away game atmosphere, it's worth a stop for a pint.
author: P D.

description:
Had some excellent beer here before a game a few weeks ago. So good, that I couldn't even drink the piss they sold in the stadium and had to return post game to wash my mouth out with some of their decent draft.

Yes, it's crowded on game day and I can't rate the food or table service, but perfect for hanging out at the bar. Super clean complete with purse hangers under the bar. 

Can't wait to return, game or no game!
author: Rebecca S.

description: Had brunch before the game - ordered a breakfast sandwich. Assumed the egg was scrambled. Noone asked me my preference. It came with egg over easy, the yoke broke, the bread got totally soggy, it was so messy to try and eat like a sandwich. Bacon was cooked to death. Talked to the waiter - no offer to take it off the bill. So I didn't eat it. Won't go back.
author: Diane H.

description: Public House is built into AT&T stadium and has a huge selection of beers on tap.  It was nice that you could take your beer into the stadium but the prices were higher than the bars down the street.
author: Ross W.

description:
This place is poorly managed. The only thing it has going for it is that it serves food and beer next to a ball park. I had called and  inquired about getting some tables together for an event  in 4 months, "not a problem" they said, month later they called to see what the minimum I was planning to spend. I said I couldn't give them a definite number, but I gave out a number, but assured them it could be more and that I'd get back to him. He said that he'd email me the menu and prices. 2 weeks later, the email never got to me , and when I called him, he told me companies with larger wallets had priority (since he and his boss went over the numbers), he said he was "just about to call me to tell me this". Sure you were. 
I've been to some Giants game, and have eaten here. Its about the same as microwaving some frozen food from the supermarket across the street but with the slight possibility that Tim Lincecum might wander in with the munchies.
meh.
author: Max R.

description:
ON game-days, this joint seems to be more crowded than anywhere you have ever been. And yet it is not a bad place to suck down a lively pint and catch some camaraderie. 

BUT if you can muster your best seating karma and jockey a table or a place at the bar, this is a hectic but chill place to pass a few innings. 

AND the twenty (?) ales on tap, full bar, snappy bar food and perky waiters don't come cheap by most sports bar standards - but they be way cheaper than the ballpark and way tastier to boot.
author: Kingpin X.

description:
I ate here for the first time during yesterday's Battle of the Bay game. It was freezing outside so me and my friends decided to eat somewhere warm. 

The burger I got was $13, but that was just for the burger. I was hesitating  to order this because it didn't come with a side of anything, but I wasn't disappointed at all! Within seconds my burger was gone. It was that good!!!! Not only is the food good, but the waiters are very attentive even after you're done paying for the check. There are TVs everywhere and it's a great place to go especially if it's freezing in the park.
author: Anne A.

description:
Our dinner here tonight made me question the integrity of the establishment. 

We had a Bloomspot certificate for a shared appetizer, 2 entrées and a shared dessert, with a claim of $71 value. Even if you order the most expensive items from those category, the most the tab can add up to is $64. The total of the food we ordered, using the above criteria came to $56, but they deducted $55 as the value of certificate. It wouldn't have been worth the time and breath to argue over a $1 if not for the fact that the steak entrée we got came with 2 lbs of french fries and 3 oz of steak. Price? $20. I appreciate heeding health professionals' advice to limit consumption of protein to 3 oz, but how do the french fries factor into that healthy equation? OK, so the food is overpriced. And why not, there's a built in clientele from the Giants games. But to add insult to injury, on my way to the bathroom, I spotted some gent's dinner of the same steak entrée and his had at least 1.5 times the amount of steak as what we got. When I questioned the waiter, who was mostly nonexistent and inattentive when he did come around, on the discrepancy in what we got vs. the gent a few tables over, he replied that the serving sizes didn't vary depending on whether a discount was used. I was sure that was going to be the answer, but needed to put them on notice that it was obvious.

And the beer we ordered, which was listed as 16oz on the menu, came in a 16oz glass, with a 1 inch head, and 1 inch clearance from the top of the glass. Think I'll give a call to the good people at the county Weights and Measures department.

The food overall was ordinary at best. The french fries were decent (thank goodness, it was what filled us up), and the texture of the homemade pasta was good. But the asparagus in the pasta dish was overcooked to that sickly grey shade of green and the bay shrimp were too salty.

Not coming back and will be telling all my friends and family of this experience, especially the Giants fans, so they can spread the word too.
author: Love Food A.

description: I usually expect large national brewer offerings at sporting venues, but this place had a terrific small batch craft beer list, and a very knowledgeable staff that made terrific recommendations. We also very much enjoyed the onion rings. Great place to grab a beer and watch some games. It was perfect for Sunday football.
author: Christopher B.

description:
Probably only fun when an actual Giants game is going on at the same time as the place is made perfectly w/ that in mind. 

-: Over priced food, tiny portions, and there's just so much more the city has to offer than this place.  Plus, when you're watching the game, the usual brat and sauerkraut is ideal, not some fancy version of it. Although, if that's what you're looking for, then this place is it!

I'd go back occasionally  to watch sports and enjoy a glass of unique beer, but that's about it.
author: Tammy T.

description:
Obviously, this place is completely packed when there's a Giants game and you have to fight for a spot to dine. I play to win, so I've never had a problem with this; but if you're not hyper competitive and are nice to strangers, you might not have the same experience as me.

Good selection of beer, good appetizers (except the jalapeño poppers - they give you a salsa dipping sauce that isn't very impressive). 

Last time I was here, I was wearing some Yelp schwag. I don't like showing my burst pride in restaurants because I'm paranoid business owners will think I'm soliciting bribes in exchange for good reviews. I would never do this and want to avoid that conversation at all costs, so I tried to conceal my Yelp apparel and hope no one would notice. Despite my attempts, the owner caught sight of me and jokingly accused me of trying to ruin his business. After chatting for a bit, he told me that the previous week some woman had moseyed in after closing and was so drunk she was barely making sense. She was mortally offended when security escorted her out. Her last words were, "You'll hear about this on Yelp!"

Turns out she was right: you're hearing about it from me.
author: Rebecca P.

description: We came in on Thursday evening. We arrived at about 6 PM. We were meeting a friend from out of town and *thought* it would be cool to show him AT & T park and this restaurant.
