We had been here once before and thought it was a good scene. We waited about 15 minutes for someone to come take our order (no problem we were waiting for our friend). When we did order it took FOREVER for each menu item to come -- well those that actually showed up. We ordered the pretzels which just never made it to the table and our server never came by to check on us so we could request them. We needed to leave at 8:20 to catch the train. We FINALLY caught our server at 7:40 to bring our check (which I asked to be split.  She brought back the bill and ran away (oh an the bill was not split). At 8:10 I got the attention of a manager so that we could close our bill (30 minutes without seeing our server). I told him we needed to make the train and needed to leave promptly. I mentioned some of the issues -- slow service (the restaurant was not busy).He brought back our bill -- still not split correctly and offered us a dessert -- um I just told you we needed to leave for the train? Nice way to offer something you knew we would never take. We will never come back our bring a guest. Shame on the management here!
author: Christine V.

description: Mini corn dogs + amazing beer selection = great restaurant. The staff is great in helping choose a beer (so many selections!) that you'll love. Come pre-game or just come down and enjoy an out of town game while killing the Pulled Pork Sliders. Seriously, delicious.
author: Matt J.

description:
Since I've already written about the beer at Public House, I thought I'd follow up with a limited report about the food.

Denied the joy of celebrating a World Series victory since the team moved to San Francisco from New York in 1958, Giants fans also have suffered through a couple of culinary missteps outside the Giants' gorgeous China Basin digs. But with the opening of Public House, coinciding with the start of the 2010 season, fans finally have a go-to player at 24 Willie Mays Plaza.
One reason the previous tenant, Acme Chophouse, didn't make the cut was that its game plan was tilted toward "fine" (whatever that means) sit-down dining. That too-formal strategy was at odds with the casual atmosphere fans expect before a baseball game. Redesigned inside and out, Public House seems to have corrected the stodgy atmosphere and the restaurant/pub now feels more casual, airy and welcoming.
The entrance to the room is dominated by two large bars that face one another. The bar on the left is mostly for mixed drinks and wine while the bar on the right is primarily for beer (the empty beer kegs are a dead giveaway). You can order anything from either bar. However, the two bars form a sort of funnel as you proceed deeper into the room, creating a potential bottleneck for bartenders and wait staff scurrying back and forth (staff refers to it as the "kill zone"). It will be interesting to see what creative steps Public House takes to avoid congestion. Beyond the bar are some tables, a large, open kitchen and the turnstile entrance to AT&T Park. There are also tables in front of the bar in a patio that is designed to be warmed by heaters below the sidewalk rather than space heaters.
The menu features beer-friendly appetizers and pub food like fish and chips, a BLT, a variety of hotdogs and sausages, sliders, a burger and salads. Considering the location and the quality, prices are not outrageous. Unlike in Philly, you will not find Velveeta on Thom's Cheesesteak Sandwich ($12). Instead, there's a nice pile of tender, juicy beef, grilled onions and sweet peppers encased in a soft, fresh roll. Although the sandwich is not huge, it's very tasty and big enough to share as an appetizer. The Mac-n-Cheese appetizer ($5), a holdover from Acme Chophouse, is not to be missed. It arrives piping hot, with melted yellow cheese atop soft, creamy elbow noodles. Matched with an Allagash White or an Ommegang Pale Ale, the cheesesteak and mac 'n cheese combo is almost as satisfying as a Brian Wilson strikeout to close out a game. Just like with your beer or alcoholic beverage of choice, you can take the food inside the park with you.
Dave McLean, owner of the Magnolia Gastropub and Brewery and The Alembic in the Haight, was on hand to help inaugurate the new baseball season and the new pub with a special beer brewed just for Public House. McLean called his cask-conditioned English ale "Billy Sunday Bitter," which combines the name of an 19th century baseball player turned evangelist with a Grateful Dead lyric from Ramble on Rose* (if you spend more than 10 minutes at Magnolia, you're bound to hear some Dead). Billy Sunday the ale is the kind of beer you might have in a cask in England: naturally carbonated and served at cellar temperature (rather than refrigerator cold) so that you can appreciate all the nuances of the beer. It seemed somewhat hoppy for an English style bitter but was delicious nonetheless.
Having Dave McLean and Magnolia onboard, along with beer from several local breweries, helps establish Public House as part of the San Francisco beer scene and might even make China Basin a beer destination beyond the estimable 21st Amendment a couple of blocks away.
The Giants seem finally to have a lineup of decent hitters and one of the best pitching staffs in baseball, playing in one of the most beautiful parks in the country. And for the first time since the park opened in 2000, long-suffering Giants fans have a pub worthy of a pennant contender. Who knows? Maybe this really will be their year after all.

Public House
24 Willie Mays Plaza
San Francisco, CA 94107
415.644.0240

No reservations



*Ramble on Rose
(Words by Robert Hunter; music by Jerry Garcia)

Just like Jack the Ripper
Just like Mojo Hand
Just like Billy Sunday
In a shotgun ragtime band
Just like New York City,
Just like Jericho
Pace the halls and climb the walls
Get out when they blow
author: chuck l.

description:
Right next to the stadium - check.  Good selection of bar food - check.  spacious and lots of room - check.  Good beer selection - check.

Great bar to go to if you're in the area.  Just watch out for big game nights when this place gets packed.  Its also on pricey side for a bar but then again this place is new and  pretty.
author: Eric A.

description:
This is definitely a good change from Acme! My husband and I were pretty pleased with the makeover. Food was good and simple - yes overpriced but compared to other restaurants in the neighborhood, this on the affordable side. We ordered the burger and a dog. Both were satisfying. The chopped salad was my favorite. Maybe that's because I love a lot of different veggies in my salad - but there was also chicken and bacon in it! 
One weird thing about this place is that they carded you at the door. I don't see how it's a very good idea to only cater to the 21+ crowd. Since baseball is a family outing and all... 
We are always looking to eat in the neighborhood (not just on game days) so it will be interesting to see what the weekly lunch hours are or the off season hours looks like. 
Staff was really friendly. We'll be back soon.
author: T K.

description: Genius move putting this bar where it is. You get the atmosphere of the game and are connected to the stadium entrance anytime you need. Gone are the days of pregaming until game time and looking up from your third beer at the last batter of the third inning. Not only can you be at your seat in 5 minutes, but the crowd will generally thin to the point of a visual cue around game time anyways. Great atmosphere and good beer. Hard to beat before a Giants game
author: Taylor C.

description:
I mean, I can't really accurately review this place as my entire time here was spent standing and/or stalking tables to sit. People will do desperate things to find a seat in this madhouse, especially during World Series or Playoff Giant's games.... as they should. We stalked a table for nearly an hour and ended up loosing it to a guy who at the last second bought the entire table a round of drinks.... touche dude, touche. 

Overall, beer selection is pretty awesome, and they make strong cocktails which is a plus too. It's always fun paying $10 for a cocktail that ends up being a cup full of ice and watery soda with a splash of liquor. The ambiance is nice too.

Too crowded, small bathrooms and the waitresses are slightly c*nty when stressed. Your a waitress.... in San Francisco..... get used to it hunny!
author: Saralina B.

description:
Been here many of time for Giants games. Walk in and get a beer to go, better prices than inside that's for sure. The game in on so you don't miss any action. But I lost a pair of glasses about a month ago at the game and on a whim I decided to ask if they had a lost and found and if they were there. The manager checked twice and even brought out a pair he thought might be what I was describing. Gotta give it up to the costumer service he and the bartender gave me. Thanks for even making enjoy the Public House even more.

Did I mention they have some of the best selection of IPA's around. My personal favorite beer of choice.
author: David G.

description:
This review is solely focused on the food as my fiancé and I got food to-go and brought it into the park to enjoy. Our interactions inside we're brief, but I will admit the bartender was friendly and polite delivering our order quickly. 

Needless to say by the amount of stars, we were extremely disappointed. We ordered the chipotle wings and the cheesesteak sandwich, both of which had some egregious mistakes as far as food should taste. The wings were extremely one note in flavor. I could see the pepper seasoning and the chipotle sauce/ glaze on the wings, but from a restaurant of chef Tracy des Jardins one should be able to expect much better and the flavor was simple and lacking in depth. My second biggest concern was on the cheesesteak sandwich. The meat to bread ration was appalling; when I examined my half of the sandwich the meat was not even covering a full layer of the bread. Clearly the portioning is aimed at drunken baseball fans who could care less. The sandwich came with chips of the kettle cooked variety? They seemed soggy but that may have been due to the transportation time to our seats, either way not good value for money.

Some positives: the roll for the cheesesteak was delicious, I believe it was a ciabatta roll, but the menu seems to be offline today? The dipping sauce with the wings was clearly homemade and satisfactory.

My advice is to avoid this place if your intention is to eat a delicious meal in a well known and Top Chef Masters contestants' restaurant as the quality has lowered severely and the prices must have increased($15 dollar cheesesteak!)
author: Grant C.

description:
This place is infinitely better than Acme was - very cool decor and a beer list to make even the most hardened beer snobs swoon.

My one complaint is that they need to do as Acme did and create a non-gameday happy hour. I get that they want to take Giants fans for everything they're worth. Really, I do. Working on Berry St I've often pondered ways to do it myself ("Pet rock with Giants logo? That'll be $20"). And it's new and shiny right now so they've got plenty of patrons, but without a happy hour they will soon find themselves a barren wasteland when the Giants aren't in town. There are enough offices in the area to support this establishment, but you gotta make it worth our while!
author: Kristen B.

description:
Ahh the Public House.  The wife and I were there on Saturday 10/23/2010 when the Giants clinched the NL and conquered the "Phaillies."  As good as it gets.  The bartenders are awesome the food was good, the mac and cheese was especially good.  And the Giants won.  A good time was had by all.  

But $6.50 for Bud Light?  Really?  

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_D-lLwdfLmU
author: Anthony Y.

description:
I walked into this place right after they opened at 4pm on a non-game day and sat at the bar. The bartender was very knowledgeable about the beer selection and let me sample a couple before settling down to a Crystal Wheat pint.

The chicken sandwich I had was worth the $12. The lettuce was crisp, the tomato was perfectly ripe, the cheese was melted alongside the expertly seasoned grilled chicken and the bread/roll was heaven.

I noticed and wondered how they utilized their own entrance into At&t park... guess I'll have to find out on a game day.
author: Nici G.

description: I went here on a non-gameday and I wasn't that blown away with the menu.  The highlight of this places is the tvs on every corner.  The prices seemed like they were only high because it was connected to the stadium, plus the fries were horrible nothing like the fries inside the stadium.  I'd rather get a margarita and food from Mijita next door.
author: Lisa H.

description:
One of my favorite places to grab a beer in SFO.  If you like baseball you just hit the bonus round as it is right at the giants ballpark.  Sometimes can be hard to grab a spot during giants games @ home, but you would come to expect that for a home game, where the bar is attached to the stadium.

1) Awesome environment to catch a sports game.  Tv's all over the place, and multiple sports events on. Always a crowd whether it is march madness to hockey, to football.

2) They make a pretty good burger.  The fish and chips are amazing too, but then again, you cant mess up fried food.  Other items are ok, but rem you came there to drink not to be feed a 5 course meal.

3) Amazing beer selection from all over the place.  You can have local IPA's to very strong belgium beers ( my fav)

Highly recommend.
author: Kevin T.

description:
We had a similar experience as Tim B when we were browsing for a weekend lunch spot. Zero interest in service... and there wasn't even a soccer match on. They probably make a killing during baseball games, so I guess they could care less.

Bottom line -- never come here except for game days and evenings.

I give it 3 stars just because they have a nice beer selection that I will eventually imbibe from on game days.
author: Derrick L.

description:
I stopped here with a girlfriend over the weekend and  had a great experience. 

We were offered samples of our beer before ordering a pint...and the beer was delicious.  We stayed on to watch several different sports at the same time: hockey, golf and gymnastics.  We split a cheeseburger which was within the top five best burgers I've ever had. Ever. We also ordered the sweet potato fries and loved them.  

Not the cheapest place in the world, but the food is delicious, the atmosphere is great and I can't wait to go back when Basbeball season starts!
author: Jessica C.

description:
The Good:  Tons of really good beer.  The former space has been split w/Mijita so it is not too big, but still a good sports bar size.  Tons of TV's everwhere, so easy to catch a view of the game.

The Bad:  (and this is obviously pretty bad for me to give 1 star...)  The food is disgusting.  We ordered the sliders, mac n' cheese , fries and blt.  The blt tasted like cooking gas, and everything else was beyond greasy.  I would have mentioned this to the server (who was nice and competent) but at this point had lost all confidence in the food and just wanted to leave.  You truly could not pay me to eat there again, and this is coming from a person who loves her burgers, fries, shakes, blt's.

Please save your money and stomach (because you will have a stomach ache) and go to Pete's or Mijita's
author: S C.

description: Great place to catch a game and have a few beers.  Great selection of beer on tap and the burgers are quite tasty.  In my few visits here I have learned a few things about Public House...  Arrive early (I mean before 10 am) for any big sporting event if you want to actually sit down.  Also the bar staff can be a bit rude at times.  Overall, great sports bar atmosphere with good food.  Parking is a joke so take a cab or bus it.
author: Matt J.

description:
Great beers and happy hour appetizers.  Plenty of tables inside, with lots of TVs.  Favorites are the mac and cheese, corn dogs and nachos.

Dogs allowed on the patio.  The waitress even brought over a water bowl and some dog treats.

Obivously crowded on game days.
author: Steve L.

description:
Chalk it up to opening night jitters maybe, but it was a rough start for public house this weekend.  It has promise though. GREAT beer selection on tap - very high-quality beers you don't see everyday.

Food is good (elevated pub food) and expensive for what you get.

Service was pretty brutal, but I'm sure it will get better as they get some busy nights under ther belts.  They don't serve food until 4p for night games (at least that was the case on Saturday 4/10 for the weekend night game.  But there is a Mijita connected (same owner) and they are cool with you taking a table and bringing food and drink over.
author: Benjamin S.

description: My wife and I ate here a few months ago before a Giants game and I am rating it 4 stars simply for the general ambiance and the fact that it is a great sports bar. I like the fact that it is first come first serve, and one can literally find the next open table as opposed to waiting to be seated. A lot of TV's around to keep track of the games that are going on, and the outer area is very nice on a warm day. Food was good, not great and a bit overpriced in my opinion for a sandwich and potato chips. It was not that memorable, but the atmosphere was and we will definitely go back if only for that reason.
author: Jeremy R.

description:
Hard to judge this place because we came right after the Giants playoff game yesterday... I know.. You are jealous...

The place was packed but you could still move around and we even found a place to sit.. 

They have plenty of staff, including security for the drunks....

The beers came out pretty quick..

I think we might go back again to catch a baseball game on one of the numerous tvs.....
author: Joe B.

description:
This is a new place that replaced Acme House near the ballpark. I went there for the first time when they played the Brewers and THERE WAS A LINE TO GET IT!!! My friend and I were like WTF?!?! Apparently there was a long line because they were "short on staff". Once we got in it was super packed and you could not move...but I guess that is expected since it is right at the ballpark. Once the game started we got a table and sat. We had a couple of beers and some food. I would say the price you pay there for food & alcohol is about the same price you would pay for that stuff at the ballpark maybe just a dollar or $2 cheaper but you lose that in paying for tax, tip, and the healthy tax (DAM U SF!!). 

They also do not have the usual beers you get at some other places. They did not have blue moon. But they gave us some "witch" beer that was okay tasting. We also got an order of french fries that were pretty good and buffalo wings. It was pretty regular, nothing special. 

But if you are looking for a place to chill before the game its not a bad place. But its not cheap either.
author: Annie L.

description: You can't beat the convenience of the Public House if you're getting dinner and catching the game.  We walked in 45 min before the game and were able to sit right down and order.  The food was just ok, the burgers were pretty bland.  They had a full bar and great selection of beers on tap, mostly local, no imports.  The atmosphere was pretty crazy with everyone there for the game.  It's a good place to hang out before the game but the food is pretty second rate.
author: Daniel W.

description:
Totally love the vibe in this place while I was watching game 3 of the world series.

It was basically packed that night but all the staff made sure everyone was served in a timely manner.  

I got the liberty ale + mijita nacho's and they were delish!

Will be going back there this afternoon to watch game 5!

See you there :)
author: Monica K.

description: Could've been a 5 star.  Great Service.  Great Selection of Draft Beers.  Nice clean bathrooms.  But our party all agreed the beer could've been colder.  Only had beer so we can't comment on the food.  Will be back for sure.
author: Stella C.

description:
The magnolia ph's Billy Sunday bitter reminds me of drinking at the Ladbroke arms in London.  
Fried chicken was great, Lamb burger is a top 10.  Go on a non game day.
author: Pam M.

description:
With "Mijita" adjoined/ 1/2 connected to the "Public House", we could have food from one side and sit to drink the Public House beer on the other while watching the Shark's game-cool idea.

Service was attentive, up-beat and fun.

Enjoyed the Deviled eggs, and the fresh chips. (But i'd pass on the nachos.)
author: Mark B.

description: Came here for the 9er/Saints playoff game and it was jam packed with people so i wasn't able to try the food, but the full bar was great!! Very nice sports bar, i wish there was something like this in the east bay...
author: Derek N.

description:
Not too fond of the name, but definitely a fan of this new SOMA/South Beach/Mission Bay eatery.  Went to Public House with a large group on its maiden voyage on probably one of the most busiest times of the year in San Francisco - The SF Giants' home opener.  I must admit, I was quite pleased with the food and the service.  Our attractive waitress (how can I forget her name!) was friendly, accommodating, and our food came out before I could even order my next drink, despite the huge crowd.

Ordered the pulled pork sliders, bratwurst, onion rings, and then, and then, and our party ordered so much food I can't even remember what was ordered.  Tasty twist on pub grub!  I'll definitely be a regular patron and will update my review after my next visit.  After all, Public House boasts "one of the largest draft beer (80% local) and cask ale offerings in San Francisco, as well as a full bar."  Until the next time....slanja!
author: Jason T.

description: Public House might be my favorite bar in the ballpark area. While it does get too blown up during game days, it can still be worth it to grab a quality beer at a cheaper price to bring into the game through their side entrance. When it's not too crowded, it boasts one of the best beer selections, the most TV's, and one of the best bar food menus in the city (bonus points for their innovative use of a tortilla under their excellent chicken nachos!).
author: Adam S.

description: Not a huge fan of the place.  I only go here because it's right by my work.  The food is meh, I'm not really impressed.  Reminds of BJ's and Chill's, greasy and nothing special yet overpriced.  The drinks are overpriced and it's always really crowded here after work (even during non-game days).  4 out of the 6 times I've been here, I've had bad experiences with obnoxious sloppy Giant's fans that are from the east/south bay that show up early during game days so that they do not need to pay a ton of money on parking.  There are so many other good places to eat and drink around the area.  This and probably Paragon are definitely my LAST RESORT.
author: Jacquelynne S.

description:
Fun atmosphere paired with an amazing selection of beers and STIFF, tasty drinks. Even though it's a "sports bar", the food is anything but typical. Lamb sliders paired with yogurt sauce anyone? Everything we ordered was quality and delicious.  

The bouncers and staff are super nice and attentive, but not so nice that they won't talk sh** to you about the game. ;) This spot is cool for anything from a date to a birthday party.  I came here twice in one weekend and will be back again. and again. In fact, I'd qualify it as one of my newest favorites in town.
author: Shree R.

description:
Came here for the World Cup Final.  Huge place, lots of TVs, great place to watch a game.  Drinks were really well-mixed and the food was pretty good. 

The crowd is...what you'd expect the crowd to be.  We were sitting at the bar watching the game and two dudes dressed in boat shoes, khakis, a tucked in checkered button-up, with a navy blue sweater wrapped around their shoulders, were chattering loudly about some finance stuff, pushed their way to the bar, and ordered...2 lattes and a hot chocolate.  And paid with a credit card.

I mean, it's SOMA, so it's no shock.  But just be prepared if that's not your usual crowd.  It wasn't mine.
author: Courtney N.

description:
I was looking forward to trying this place and wasn't very impressed at all. First off, the place wasn't packed because everyone was at the Giants game yet no one greeted us and we were pretty confused about whether we should seat ourselves or wait to be seated. Throughout the whole meal, the servers weren't very friendly. I felt like they really didn't want us there, it was kind of uncomfortable. And the place was like 90 degrees inside, we may have stayed longer and had a few more beers if the place wasn't so friggin hot!  

I ordered the fresh stuffed jalapenos as an appetizer. The order comes with two. The first jalapeno was mild and the second one was so hot I couldn't finish it and the spiciness carried on throughout the meal. 

The rest of the food was fairly good, nothing special and I didn't think the prices were too bad for San Francisco, but due to the sales tax, the 4% Health Tax, and trying to leave a good tip, we paid at least 25% more than what we would pay on the Peninsula for the same meal. 

They have a good beer selection and you get more bang for your buck than going inside the park. If we go there again we'll stick to the bar and sit near the door!
author: Marie L.

description:
*Drinks

The drinks are plentiful on the menu. There are cocktails that are tried and true as well as some things that are out of the ordinary. My feeling is that as long as the bar is fully stocked and there is a good mixologist in house then you're set so good but not overly impressed. Now the beer selection on the other hand is pretty awesome. It's hard to find a good place that has this much variety of good beer. And what's better than being able to get a specialty brew on tap that you can bring into the ballpark for cheaper than a Bud Light inside the ballpark?

*Service/Ambiance

I love the feel of game day with all the frenzy and hoopla BUT service suffers a little of course due to the crowds. It's a lively place to go before the game or just hang out at watch the game. The best part? (Yes, it get s better.) Not only can you order a beer here and take it into the ballpark but you skip that ridiculous long queue outside to get into the ballpark because there is a side entrance inside of Public House that has an extremely shorter line. 

*Overall

Maybe I should tell you not to go here so it will be less crowded. I like it too much to be mean. This place is great! Haven't tried it on a non-game day and probably won't.

Rating: 4
author: Jennifer L.

description:
I wish I could give it a 3 1/2.  On a non-game night it's a great place to be.  You and your sports-watching significant other can sit at a community table and eat grilled cheese sandwiches and burgers and drink beer until you can't remember what game you were watching.

Other menu items I liked - the chopped salad and the mac and cheese.

On game nights...get your drinks there and bring them into the park, I think it's cheaper.
author: Christine O.

description:
So, we stopped by Public House before the Giant's game.  It was a good spot to grab a few beers and food before the game with some friends.  We started at the bar, and then sat at a table before heading into the game:

Beer-4 stars
The beer selection is very good.  They have several beers on tap, as well as some unique bottled beers.  Between our party, we had a few Sierra Nevada Torpedoes ($7), a Stella ($6), two Chimays ($10), and a German Dunkel ($14).  The only reason I cannot give 5 stars is that everything was overpriced.  

Food-3
The Italian sausage with peppers and onions ($12) was very flavorful.  My wife enjoyed the romaine salad with lemon-anchovy dressing ($7) and said the dressing was tangy.  The house made chips ($3) were good, but cold and soggy in the center. Expected them to be hot.

Service-2
Our table server was a four.  He was friendly, attentive, and helped explain some of the more unique beers on the menu.  The bartender, however, needs an attitude check.  There are two bars in the restaurant, and apparently they do not have the same beers on tap (yet  the menu does not specify).  The Sierra Nevada Torpedo was on tap at a different bar.  When we first ordered a beer, the bartender went over to the other bar to grab the beer.  However, when another member of our party ordered the Torpedo, the bartender rolled his eyes and said if we wanted that beer we needed to order it from the other bar.  Really?  Not only was her rude, but perhaps PH shouldn't put beers on their menu if you cannot order them.  OK, I am off my soapbox.  Other than that, the service was fine.

Decor-3
There are plenty of seats and tables to enjoy a drink and a snack before the game.
author: Robert K.

description: First time here.  It's been on the list for a while and since i had 30 minutes to kill before the Giant's game, i decided to have a beer and a snack.  The place was hopping obviously since it was a Friday night Giant's game.  I had the nachos and a Lagunitas and sat outside.  The chicken nachos was pretty flavorful and they gave plenty.  Beer was excellent.  They have a great selection.  It's a nice sports bar and packed, but I've also gone by many times and it's been empty.  My tab for the meal was a bit pricey, but it's what i expected being by ATT Park and Momo's.  I'd come back to try the pork sliders and a few of the other items.
author: Gerry T.

description: $18.00 for most pitchers and their bloody mary is amazingly delicious.  This is the perfect spot to hang out before hitting up the games.
author: Oriana C.

description:
Wait Time: Zero. Place is usually never busy.

Staff: Very friendly and attentive.

Decor: Cool, clean, brewery type feel. Good sized space

Food: Pretty good. We split deviled eggs, mac and cheese, onion rings, and the burger with avocado on it. Deviled eggs were pretty spicey, I probably wouldn't order those again, but everything else was good. 

Drinks: This place seems more geared towards the beer drinkers as they have a big selection of beers. I ordered an alcoholic pink lemonade and it was so strong that I had to add water to it. I think I'd get a beer next time.

This place is definitely worth a try, especially if you live close by like I do. I wouldn't say this is my favorite place to go, but I would go back again.
author: Kate C.

description:
I thought I'd try something different before the game since I've been to many of the nearest places to ATT already. I've always been leary of this location in the past, anticipating high prices for food and drinks. Sure enough, they have high prices for food and drinks. But, they have a great selection of beers on tap and easy access to the stadium thru the bar. Best of all, you can take a GO-CUP of your drink of choice into the park.
I had a lamb meatball sandwich. The meatballs were very tasty served with a garlic-yogurt sauce. But, there were only two small meatballs served on a hot dog bun, no sides or chips.. At $10, I would have liked to see, at least, more meat and better bread.
Service was pretty fast considering the pre-game rush. I may skip the food next time, but for beers before the game, it's great.
author: Pete S.

description:
So we came back with a buddy on a non-game night, and it was awesome! To clarify, my beef with the place isn't so much that it's slow, I know it's gonna be slow when there's a million people inside. Duh. It's the open seating+the lack of organization amongst the servers, they just kept missing our whole section standing int he middle of the dining room at the circular standup table. 

SO, when there's a light crowd it's great. One of the best beer lists in the city bar none, minus the attitude (cough cough Toronado cough) and they take credit cards, as any 21st century business should. Humphrey Slocombe ice cream for dessert doesn't hurt either. The food is good. Servers are friendly even when it's busy, and it's a convenient location for driving with a decent amount of st. parking nearby, and the N and T stop right there! love it.
author: Christopher V.

description:
Came here last night, following its "official" opening and Giants' season opener. Given the scenario, I'll give them some slack for pretty much running out of every type of beer that my fiancé asked for....he probably tried to order 4-5 different types, only to be met with, "Oh, we ran out of that one too." In all fairness, it's understandable since they had just opened - it makes sense from a biz perspective - but am hoping they fix that problem ASAP as it's pretty certain this place will become a huge hit in the SOMA area. 

The food is great - we were pleasantly surprised by the mac & cheese (and I'm super picky about mac) and burger. This place has a lot of promise and is a great addition to the area...can't wait to see how it evolves.
author: Adrienne C.

description:
*cue theme to Cheers*

I came here last night (a non-game night) with Lan H. I thought the service was top notch-- the manager, John,came by to say hi to LH and we met another one of the managers, Nathan. They even comped us some Secret Breakfast ice cream from Humphrey Slocombe since the GM remembered this was LH's favorite.

As for the food, I thought everything was delicious. I am a devout lover of mac and cheese everywhere and Public House's mac and cheese did not disappoint! Also had the jalapeno poppers (beware the heat!), chicken wings, and potato salad. I thought everything was good and they have a many specialty beers on tap that can compliment your food. I really enjoyed this place and I'm glad there's food at the ball park a little more down to earth than the former Acme steakhouse.
author: Angela L.

description:
Came here with a few friends for some drinks. Ordered chicken nachos and fries to munch on.  Server said if we decided to order more food later, we could and that it'd be quick because the kitchen wasn't busy.  We waited over 20 minutes and politely asked where our food was.  Without apologizing for the delay, they said it was on its way.  They probably forgot to put in the order.  A table that was seated after us received their food before ours.

Servers weren't attentive.  They were lazy and had loads of attitude.

Will definitely not come back.
author: TJ S.

description: Cool place. Non game day stop was still hopping. Nachos and mac&cheese were legit.... though I felt like I ate a brick of butter! Great service.
author: Danny M.

description: Public House is THE place to be before a Giants game- tons of TVs, great food, and an energetic vibe that lasts through the final out.  Their sandwiches and burgers are awesome, and don't pass on the sweet potato fries- they are fantastic!  It can be a little tough finding a table, especially for larger parties, since they don't take reservations and don't have a hostess, but the staff at Public House is attentive and makes sure your food is out before you have to rush to your seats before first pitch!
author: Shannon W.

description: I would give this zero stars if it was an option.  Came here after work for a beer with a friend and after finishing our beer we were asked to give up our small table because our 'conversation' was taking to long.  The kicker is that the manager Charlie was the one that kicked us out.  We have frequented public house in the past and i can say this will be our last time.
author: Matt D.

description:
overpriced, but i didn't expect anything else from a bar/restaurant under the giant's stadium. 

The food is, eh... nothing special and again overpriced. The only reason we ate here was because we couldn't find tickets to the game. As i was sitting there i asked myself, why would anybody come here? would someone go out of their way to come here? WHY? 

i'd take the extra time to head inland and go someplace else.
author: Caitlin F.

description: The food here is pretty gross, but the drinks are cheap and it's a great place to watch the game, unless there are a bunch of people standing in front of your table.
author: Joe N.

description: Tried to go here for lunch on Saturday....there was a night game so there wasn't the restaurant wasn't that busy. The place has a sign that says seat yourself, alright....so I sat outside with my dog and a waitress came out fairly fast. After saying I wanted a side car shes like 'HUH???' where I then had to point to the drink on the menu. Got the drink, it was ok I guess. She said she'd come back to take our food order...hour later my friend had to go in to ask for a check. Twenty minutes later we finally get the check, $42 for four drinks...WTF. The funny thing is whenever someone else would come and sit outside the same waitress would do the same, this place blows.
author: phil c.

description:
First off, if I had to rate this restaurant/pub only of their beer selection, they'd receive 5 stars. They probably have one of the best beer selections in the city. I've been a few times before ball games and a few times during the World Cup games. It's always been busy and the bartenders have always been friendly and attentive. 

While drinking at the bar I've ordered the nachos and a small chopped salad. It's hard to expect a lot...it's a bar and it's bar food. The nachos were ok, but not worth getting again. The chopped salad was missing the bacon (which in my opinion is the best thing about a chopped salad!) It wasn't horrible, but I wouldn't order either of these things again. 

Again, if I was rating this place on their beer selection alone, they'd receive 5 stars. It's a great place to grab some beers before a game and I'll definitely be back. If your hungry I'd suggest getting a bite elsewhere.
author: Heidi H.

description:
Ok - admittedly I live across the street and I come on days that aren't as crowded (watching some NFL and getting Sunday brunch). BUT:

* service is always super friendly
* food is super tasty - I had the nachos and thought it was delicious and portion was large and on another visit the huevos rancheros which were super tasty

Sad to see the unhappy reviews so I had to put in my two cents. I like it and recommend it!
author: Mona T.

description:
Went back on a Thursday non-game night and it was bumpin'. Fish and chips and Burger are tasty.   Chad was our waiter this time and he brought out the malted vinegar for my F&C as I was contemplating what was missing from my dish.  Yippee!  Had another good meal there and enjoyed the fun atmosphere. They get a solid 4 stars from me and I'll be back soon.

Update: It's now 2015 and it's a regular place for me, Husband, and Kid.  They have highchairs and bring crayons and paper for the little one.  They serve Humphreys Slocombe on their dessert menu and the butterscotch pudding is still so mouth-watering.
author: Nina L.

description: I never went here in relation to a Giants game, in fact I generally avoided it during those times. Having lived nearby for a while, Public House is great for a quick sandwich or simple breakfast on the quiet days when there is no home game happening. The menu is limited, but things like the chicken sandwich are great for an economical yet tasty meal. Best of all, when the Giants are away you are basically the only person eating there so the staff are attentive and never busy.
author: Ryan B.

description:
An improvement over ACME in terms of convenience. Casual is better than upscale when just dropping in for a beer and a snack. 

The beer selection is good - many good local micros on tap, several Belgians in bottles, and even a few Belgian-style micros on tap. Big plus for a selection of (2) beers from the cask. 

My food experience has been going downhill steadily. My first meal - andouille sausage - was a winner. I was thinking 4 stars based on the food/beer. My next meal was the cheese steak sandwich. Huge disappointment, especially after the hype on the menu. 3 stars. My most recent was the pulled pork sliders and romaine salad with anchovy vinaigrette. The pork was DRY. The salad dressing was SALTY. 2 stars. Come on Public House, you're losing me, fast. 

Another problem is the price. With 2 beers, and a simple meal, my bill came to about $45 with tax and tip. That's going to make it tough for me to keep coming back. Maybe coupons for locals?
author: Bib G.

description: Don't steal the K's fixed to coat hooks at Public House!  People will come after you.  Do ask politely if they can spare an extra K to keep at your table.  Do arrive early so you can actually get a seat at the bar or anywhere up front with the single people.  Otherwise, you will end up stuck at a communal table in the back with women who sip iced tea and knit while their husbands watch the game.  Good deviled eggs though.
author: Camille K.

description:
I love the vibe in Public House, what a cool place to grab a beer, watch a game, or meet up friends.

Their beer selection is outstanding, and the staff is actually pretty knowledgeable in all of them and can always recommend a fun one depending on your mood! The food is really good and they use a lot of fresh local ingredients. Apparently they are launching a pretty cool Happy Hour which I'm excited for.

A lot of people don't know 2 of the best things about this place: 
1) you can bring your food from Mijita (the Mexican place it shares the space with) if you prefer PH's pub atmosphere/giant TVs ; 
2) You can bring any food or drink you buy at PH into the ballpark during a game! They have a special door into the ballpark so you can come back as many times as you want to grab more beers or nachos. The food and beer is so much better/cheaper than concession, what a hidden gem!
author: Elsa L.

description: Beers are $3 cheaper than from inside the park, and you can walk into the park itself  from restaurant? I like! There are a ton of TVs in here and it's always pretty crowded with large groups of baseball fans. Have yet to try the food- going to my share of games this year so will update once I do.
author: Geralyn Y.

description:
We came here for drinks before a game.  Our waitress was attentive.  
We had a couple of good beers, one was the sublime which my husband really enjoyed.  
We plan on coming back to taste the food.
author: Lizete S.

description: Location, location, location.  That's how Public House gets away with charging $20 for a pitcher of Racer 5.
author: Suo L.

description:
I've eaten here as Public House at least three times. Why I haven't written a review, I don't know. 

The perfect time: tonight. I went there looking for dinner. I had eaten at Amici's last week and didn't want a repeat, but it took a lot of work to find a place to eat. I looked over the menu and I think it has changed since I was last there or I just don't remember. I looked over the menu and the waiter was very good at explaining if we had any allergies that we could have things changed out. I wanted fish and chips, but didn't want the chips because I wasn't sure if they would be fat fries or skinny fried. I asked the waiter to substitute the fries for onion rings. Not a problem. 

My friend had ordered a sandwich and fried. When the meal arrived I was shocked. I thought the sandwich was a bit small, but the fries looked like the ones from In-N-Out, but just slightly bigger and with the potato skin. The fish and chips were good. There were two pieces of big fish, but not too big and one half the size of the big ones. The onion rings weren't battered a lot so it sort of look like a light tempura-ish coating.

The fish was battered fresh and not frozen and it was good. The onion rings were good except the chef put salt on them. I thought they were a bit salty. The fries were good too, but they had a bit too much salt on them. 

Overall pretty good. I just wish the chef would leave the salt off and let us salt it our self to our liking. I'd come back. I wasn't too hungry, but it was filling. My friend had a sandwich (don't remember which) and he said it was filling in the end. 

It was good and the tv's were full of sports and a good even amount of baseball, hockey, and basketball. The plus side is that there's free wi-fi in there because it's part of the ballpark.
author: Jen C.

description: Sports bars are not my thing, but my friends wanted to have a drink here before dinner elsewhere. So I guess by sports bar standards Public House is a decent one. It's not a dark and dank hole-in-the-wall. There's more than one television screen. It doesn't smell like stale cigarettes or vomit. I guess as far as sports bars go it's a-ok in my book, so I'll remain neutral on this one.
author: Anastasia B.

description: Big, fun sports bar at AT&T Ballpark. The crowd is cool, and the bartenders are super friendly. They also have a good beer selection on tap, like Firestone Double Barrel, which I don't see that often anymore. I also liked how the bartender remembered my drink, always a nice plus!
author: Sonya D.

description: ....went there only once as a guest, unfortunately because you have out of town people here for the game they will go and get a bad impression of San Francisco's alleged good restaurants that actually are mostly mediocre tourist traps...
author: jim b.

description: Tried to go to Lucky Strike for beer and food, but the place was so busy that we could hardly hear ourselves think.  Luckily Public House was nearby/spacious/quiet after the Giants' home opener.  They have quite the beer selection, but can run out of more popular beers towards the end of the night.  My friend highly recommended the burger, and I'm glad I took that recommendation!  The burger was perfectly cooked and the secret sauce on it is delicious!  $15 for a burger is pretty pricey though.  Overall, I had a good experience at Public House and I'd love to come back during a Giants game!
author: Mousputin S.

description: The food is surprisingly good for a place where you're likely to have hundreds of pounds of man leaning against you when you're grabbing a beer before the "torture" of a Giants game. You can grab tacos next door at Mijita and bring them into the Public House, but the servers won't bring the tacos to you, and why should they, you lazy bum? Catch a KNBR broadcast on the deck, and chat it up with Marty Lurie during commercial breaks. One suggestion to the owners: Celebrity Bartender Saturdays. I need to cross off "Have Rick Reuschel serve you a beer" from my bucket list.
author: Tim O.

description:
as i wrote on facebook, i am never buying a beer at the concession stands ever again. you can just go downstairs to the bar here, pay half the price(with 10x the selection), and take the beer upstairs to your seats. does it get any better than that? food prices looked great too, but it's all about the drinks. the restrooms are also much nicer, especially for you ladies. and the wait for drinks is nothing(like a normal bar) compared to the ridiculous lines at the concession stands. 

recap:
upstairs at the concession stands, $9.75 for a pint of coors light.

downstairs at the public house, $5 for a pint of stella.

SCORE!
author: Andrew T.

description: A great place for us to celebrate the Giant's winning! Its a cool environment with decent appetizers and drinks. Really the reason to come is to watch the Giant's win it!!! Everyone is a fan and the staff is great and friendly. They don't push you to order and let you take your time (and enjoy the ENTIRE game)!! Will definitly be back!
author: Ana A.

description: Great place to go after ball game, we saw a few ball players from opposing team come in. Food is Ok, service was excellent!
author: Monica J.

description: Came here Sunday to watch the US/England World Cup Game.  Public House was seriously not prepared for the crazy number of people who showed up on Sunday but amazingly the afternoon still went really smoothly.  The guy behind the small beer bar (sorry forgot his name already) was the nicest, most organized over-worked bartender ever.  Public House is having a WC promo where if you drink all 24 of their bottled beers you get a stein.  I drank 6 off the list on Sunday!  TVs are everywhere, there really isn't a bad seat in the place.  I didn't get a chance to eat the food there though but heading back this week so I'll keep you all posted.
author: Jen C.

description: Not bad.  Being a sports bar called "Public House" attached to one of the coolest stadiums around I might make a few tweaks but not much.  Beer list is superb.  My choice tonight is Marin County Three Flowers IPA.  Quite good.  Menu looked average.  I had the brisket.  It was tasty but a little dry.  Mashed potatoes were excellent.  Music was a little too hip at first but settled in after a while.  Eleven TVs in the front bar and plenty more in back.  I'd return if in the neighborhood, especially for the beer.
author: John W.

description: good brews, cool place to meet before a Giants game, prices for appetizers are expensive for the amount they give you (i.e. pretzel balls), gets packed and hard to even find a place to stand
author: Michelle E.

description:
This is the beer haus located at the Giants ballpark. Went there recently for a football game. I didn't expect super service at a sports bar but was surprised at the pleasant attitude and the tasty starters. Recommend Lagunitas beer...among their excellent, if not pricey selections of  brews.

The area is drop-dead gorgeous, and you can sit outside and really watch the world go by. No substitute for that.
author: jj c.

description: Its a nice meeting place before the game that's about it! The drinks are way too expensive!! I only ever order something from mejita and the nachos are pretty good.  I just go there watch some games before my GMEN games!
author: Nadia N.

description:
5 stars for the beer menu and mac and cheese alone.

double daddy ipa. IM THERE!
author: Ryan L.

description:
you know i have to say, i was kinda impressed.

we went on a tuesday night when the giants were away - so i'm wondering if that has something to do with it.

the double bars were quite impressive - and on game days i bet they make sense. but anyway.

service was attentive and really good on suggesting beer and food.

i had the iceberg wedge salad with mac and cheese and my friends had a burger, fries, onion rings, and sliders. everything was really tasty. the mac and cheese was creamy but not too sludgy thick and my salad was HUGE.

my only complaint is the price - for these things plus a beer for each person our tab came to 75.00 pre tip. holy cow!
author: laura f.

description:
Ok the novelty is over, although it's a great spot attached to the ball park thats just it - its a great spot so EVERYONE is there!  The second time we got really lucky with table because Natalie G is like a hawk and just pounced on one!  The service was slow borderline bad and orders were wrong and they seemed like they were just real annoyed with everything.  It's still a restaurant, you still have to serve people even if its at the busiest time, game time.  Food service gets slow about this time so expect to wait about 20-30 minutes for food to arrive.  Also, apparently you can't save your friends a seat.  It's not like we were saving 9 seats for people, we were saving TWO for our party that arrived two seconds later at our table of four that we scouted on our own!  They put a party of 4 in our table of 4 bringing us to 8 people at a table meant for 4.  I'm not exactly sure what I enjoyed more.  The crowded table with 4 strangers (who were perfectly nice but I did not come to hang out with them) or their massive order which took over 3/4 of the table (fine I wanted to eat it!!!).  

P.S. Don't ask us if we wan't chicken on our nachos and put it on there when we told you no and had you fix it on our receipt.  I would've been fine just not knowing there was a choice and wasting 10 minutes of my life trying to fix it only to have it show up with chicken anyway.  

P.P.S The buffalo chicken sliders looked amazing, also the deviled eggs.  Not sure though - didn't eat them, just saw that the other people at the table with us ordered it!
author: Tiffany L.

description: good place to watch the niner game before going into the giants game.  ;)
author: Helen T.

description: The burgers here are great. The prices are not too bad for the ballpark. They have a big beer selection which is kind of overwhelming.
author: Darius A.

description:
Just to start this review off, the food doesn't factor into this.  That shouldn't really be a bad thing because to be honest, I wouldn't come here to eat anyway.

That said, Public House has to be near the top for places to drink at in exceptionally close proximity to the ballpark.  Actually after a few trips here, I kind of want to come here even more when the Giants are away.  One of my favorite places to go in Chicago near Wrigley Field, was the Goose Island Brew Pub.  Like that great institution, Public House offers tons of TVs with nearly every game on.  Of course the main event is the nice list of rotating taps they have.  Rely on the chalkboards, tap handles or just the bartender (more than the menus) to keep up on what is delicious and new on tap.  During my most recent trip I enjoyed the Bruery's Saison which is practically perfect for a sunny day and finished off a delicious Old Rasputin on nitro before heading into the ballgame.  The Grab n Go stand is a great way to save at least a couple bucks on a good beer before heading into the $9.25 void of beer that has become AT&T park.

Of course during the Giants game this place is a complete madhouse and milling through the crowd or even getting a beer can be a clusterf$%&  (head to Pete's Tavern if you want less people but also a less interesting beer selection) but given that it's a spiffy TV-laden place serving tasty suds, I've thus far endured the hoards to enjoy quality pre-game beers.
author: Steven R.

description:
Public House. 

You know what's good here? The Wings. 

Meaty wings, smothered in a dark spicy sauce, that leaves you wanting more. Yep, Grab 2 orders.

Protip: Do not attempt to come enjoy wings when the Giants are playing at home.
author: Christian K.

description: Overall was very pleased with my first trip here. I'm giving it a solid 3.5 stars. Had the cheesesteak which was better than I had even anticipated it being. The beer selection isn't the best I've ever seen but it's solid and offers enough variety for everyone. Sat at the bar and the service was good. Will definitely go back
author: Nick R.

description:
Yikes, what a lousy experience. The only good thing about this place is you can enter the ball park through their doors. Other than that, don't waste your time. Not sure why everyone is raving here about "how good their beer is." It is no different than any other bar, what gives?

Our experience: we went an hour and a half before a game. Sure it was busy, but that shouldn't negate good, or even average, service. We sat down and waited 15 minutes before we were acknowledged. Ordered a chicken sandwich, that is all for food. My partner didn't order any food, just drinks. Drinks came after 15 minutes. The waitress came back after 30 minutes and said it was coming right up. 30 minutes later, we received our sandwich, just decent but nothing special at all. Total cost of the sandwich? $14.... A huge rip-off.  We asked for a check right when the sandwich was delivered so we could get to the game in time. A total of 3 waitresses came by over the next 15 minutes and asked: You guys want your check, was that right? Finally it came and we paid our bill and left. 

Trust me; don't waste your time in this place. Spend your money elsewhere where they will value your business. Such a limited menu, subpar products and horrid service should deter you away from this place.
author: mark w.

description: 5 stars on non-game days and 2 days for game days.  Great bear selection but not worth the hassle when there are hundreds of people inside.
author: Robert G.

description:
Men's Restroom overflowing with fecal matter (4/25).

It gets worse:

The sarcastic employee shrugs and says to me: "Sorry man. Restrooms are closed."

I reply, "This is the second time in one hour. You have a real problem on your hands. Your improvements are great - I like the vibe - but your accommodations don't scale!"

Employee: "It would've cost us another 20K to add more stalls."

Seems like a worthwhile investment to me.

FAIL.
author: B I.

description: Overpriced beer, overpriced frozen food. I'll never return.
author: Alfredo A.

description:
I went here the other night to check out this new restaurant in my neighborhood. It has a fun atmosphere, with lots of TVs. I had high hopes for the food, once I took a bite of their amazing crab cake! However it went downhill from there when my BF had a chili cheese dog. This was the saddest thing that ever happened to a hot dog. It was this tiny wiener on a bun, covered with this ground beef mess that was mixed with sloppy joe sauce YUCK, yuck and more yuck.

I had a gruyere grilled cheese sandwich which was OK. It had too many caramelized onions to the point where I could not taste the cheese. Besides the crab cake, what also was good was the tiburon blonde brew. If I come here again, it would only be for happy hour and I would order appetizers. But please, stay away from the hotdog.
author: Alexandra O.

description:
Came on a non-game night. Good place to watch a game and have a few drinks. Awesome selection of beers and an interesting cocktail menu. Had the "Corpse Reviver" which was super good! 

Food is pricey and could be better. Onion rings were okay, a little too crunchy for my taste. Fish and Chips were slightly soggy. 

Probably won't eat here again, but will definitely be back for a few drinks before the next Giants game.  (Plus, there is a direct entrance to ATT Park inside the restaurant)
author: Jonathan M.

description: I didn't actually eat here, but gotta give them 5 stars for just being good people. Leaving a Giants game after 11pm with a 20 month old screaming for a "baba." Who knew that nowhere in ATT Park sells milk!?!? So knocked on the already locked door and asked if they would just sell me a glass of milk. After the security conferred with the manager, they gave me a bottle full of milk- on the house, even after I offered to pay anything they asked for it. Happy baby on the drive home and happy mommy not having to try to find a liquor store, etc that was open at 11 at night. If their service to a not-paying customer was this good, they've gotta treat paying customers well!
author: Karlee N.

description: They pour weak drinks and the Nosh appetizers are not good.  Nice to sit outside but would find somewhere else to go...
author: Rachelle I.

description:
This bar is not friendly to Giants fans and it is not a good place to watch an away game.  

We tried to watch the Giants Dodgers game there this past weekend (they were in LA) and the bar refused to turn on the volume for the game bc....they had muzak playing.  This was despite the fact that most everyone was there to watch the Giants-Dodgers.  I mean....we are in a sports bar at the freakin park!

When they refused to turn on the volume, I told them we would just leave and go to one of the MANY MANY MANY bars in the area that would gladly take my money and in exchange would let me watch the Giants WITH THE VOLUME ON.  

When I pointed this out to the manager he replied, "Well, we're not owned by the Giants".  Umm okay, but you do want Giants fans as your customers right?  You are located inside our park, right?  Why should I stay there and spend $9 a drink if you cant even bother to simply accomodate your biggest customer base?

So when we go to leave the manager apologized to us and said.  "Hey I'm sorry we cant turn the volume on.  We're part of a national chain and we're just not allowed to do that"

Wow....strike three.

One would think even a national chain would want to acommodate its cutomers (i.e. Giants fans), but it seems like Public House has no such concern.

My recommendation?  Save your money and go somewhere else to watch the game when the Giants are out of town.  I recommend O'Neills, MoMo's, Pete's or Zeke's.  The drinks are much cheaper and they will appreciate your business.  I got the feeling Public House did not.

Good luck guys.  I wonder what they're going to call the place next year after you close.
author: jesse s.

description: one of my favorite pre-game traditions! you can even take your drink into the ballpark through their entrance. gets crowded, but if you can get a seat or good place by the bar...there's nowhere better to be before a game.
author: Mandy A.

description: Great place to grab a brew before or after the game. It's always busy so you have to wait a bit. Great beer selection & you can walk right into ATT park.
author: Edgar G.

description: Fun place to be during a game, especially a game for a playoff birth. It was packed and very crowded before the game time. We managed to grab a few seats on the "mexican" style side of the bar. The chips and guacamole were not that great, but the beer was tasty and easy to get. It's fun because it's at the stadium, otherwise I'd probably look to hang  out elsewhere.
author: Jeff R.

description: Four stars and this is not just because I am still on cloud nine from the win last night...but really because they deserve it.  If you don't have a ticket to the game, this is seriously the next best thing.  Back in May, June and July during a game this place had enough people but was never packed.  Usually people come here pre-game for a drink that by the time it starts most have left and you get a seat at the bar.  There are numerous televisions all playing the giants game.  There are a few different bars, but be careful because some serve some drinks and not others and that can get annoying.  But my motto is, how about I am not annoying and just order whatever the bar has I happen to be sitting at...because really you are here for the game.  Which is a good thing, because the food is terrible.  I've only ordered a few different appetizers and I could almost not get them down.  So salty.  If anything I'd get the pretzle bites and fill up on beer during the game and food somewhere else after.  If this place wasn't connected to the stadium and if it wasn't full of giants fans watchign the giants game it would get one or two stars.  But because it is both of these things it gets four stars...and I will be there next season when sadly I dont have a ticket.
author: Kierstan G.

description: The cocktails were mediocre, along with the food -  not a place I would go out of my way to avoid, nor a place I would go out of my way to go to either. It's decent, but nothing notable.
author: Roxy G.

description: Decent place to watch sports and yes they do allow dogs in the outside area. I got there a bit late to watch the Giants beat the braves and so it was full. Would have thought that i would have at least gotten some assistance from staff.
author: Pilar M.

description: Good place to watch a sports game. Especially the giants. Obvi.
author: Johanna W.

description: I was dragged here one night by a co-worker who wanted to watch the MNF game.  I had very low expectations for this place- afterall, it's a sports bar inside a ballpark.  But I was pleasantly surprised.  The chile was very good.  The draft beer selection is varied and diverse.  It was dead that night and I can't imagine it has much of scene when the Giants aren't playing that day, but I would definitely come back again if I was in the neighborhood and wanted to catch a game.
author: Mike B.

description: We stopped off at Public House while we were waiting for our friends to go into Oktoberfest by the Bay. Initially our service here was good when I order was taken. Right after we received our drinks we never saw our server again.  We had the Dragoon Stout and the Telegraph. The Telegraph beer had a slightly strange orange aftertaste but it was drinkable. It was cool that the outside area allowed dogs since there were plenty of dog owners around us.  It's a great hang out spot passing by AT&T park and I'll check the food out one of these days.
author: Chris G.

description: Very disappointing after a nice time in the ballpark. Our server was incompetent. We ordered drinks, apps and entrees. After drinks came to the table, we were asked if we still wanted our appetizers. This seemed unusual, especially when our entrees arrived right after drinks. When we explained that we expected to eat the apps first, the server offered to put our plates under the warmer until we finished our wings. Unbelievable. I ordered the cobb chicken sandwich, advertised as chicken, tomato, blue cheese, arugula, and bacon on a bun. What arrived on my plate was dried out chicken, Swiss cheese, bacon, and shredded iceberg lettuce. No tomato. Fries were cold. Only positive thing to say is that the busboys were on top of water refills. PH = FAIL
author: Kimberly S.

description:
I'll give this place 3.5 stars.  To start off with, I've never been to Acme Chophouse but Public House is a much better choice for Giants games because of the pricing; much more affordable.  I was a bit annoyed that even though our friend was inside with a table, they still made us wait in line outside which didn't make a lot of sense.  

We ordered the Chicken Sandwich, Philly Cheesesteak, Beef Sliders, Chopped Salad, Nachos, and Kracker Jax.  The Cheese steak for $10 or $12 was delicious according to my friend.  For $9, you can also get one inside the ball park which is oily and very little meat which makes this sandwich a great deal.  I had the chicken sandwich and it had fig compote and when blended with the chicken which was salty, it was a perfect combination of salty and sweet.  You could taste the different flavors it offered.  The beef sliders, I only had one, was also very delicious; juicy, tender, hot, well made.  The nachos, salad, and the kracker jax were very disappointing.  The latter stuck to your teeth before you can chew it, the salad was over priced and small, and the nachos while not too expensive just was too small and perhaps a bit innovative for ball park food.  On the bottom was a large chip or crunchy pita bread and on top of it were nachos.  I most likely wouldn't get the latter three.  

Our waiter was a nice and friendly guy but either he had too many tables to manage or he was off doing something because it was often hard to find him.

For the price of food and beer, this place offers a good value when compared to the food inside the park.  There are good bites inside as well but if you're early and don't want to wait for the game to start, getting a bite here could be worthwhile.
author: Pierre L.

description: Good place to watch sports. Bar area is huge with tons of TVs everywhere. Came here for game 7 NBA Finals last night and it was packed but still manageable. The only negative is that they did not have enough bartenders so they were ill prepared for how busy a night it was going to be but besides that good place to come eat and watch an important sporting event.
author: David C.

description:
* Review on non-Giants game night during Monday Night Foodball

DRINKS: huge selection of drafts and full bar

ATMOSPHERE: awesome number of TV's everywhere, much better layout than Acme Chophouse the previous establishment.  was not very crowded but good amount of folks on hand to watch the games

FOOD: 

* MacNCheese: a little on the greasy side but not too bad
* Lamb meatball sandwich: very good, right amount of spice with a great roll and salad greens and awesome yogurt sauce
* Chicken Pot Pie: crust was the best part, the chicken and vegetables were average

BOTTOM LINE: 

* Recommend this as your nicer sports bar with good food and though the prices of course are a little higher, to me it's worth it to enjoy this relaxing open environment.  This is my go to sports bar (when the Giants aren't playing).
author: Phil F.

description: Good fries, weird ketchup.  Ask for the dip that comes with the wings instead.  Wings are very spicy.
author: Diana C.

description: Great sports atmosphere, average food
author: Bob F.

description: I have tried the meatball sandwhich, pulled pork sliders, fries and the hot dog.  All items are at least as good as what is served inside.  What I enjoy about the place is all the TV's and the sports bar feel it brings.  The one downfall is that the place only has enough space for about 5 tables on the patio. WIth the remodel I wish they would have expanded this portion but what can you do.  O and not serving all drinks at all bars is a mess.  Hearing "we don't have ... at this bar I will have to go over and get it for you.  If you have a hard liquor bar and a beer bar you need have signs labled above the bars so people can figure it out.  Not just have people waiting in line and tell them to go to another part of the restraunt.
author: Jimmy M.

description:
This place has promise, but also a few key drawbacks. Let's start with the minuses, shall we?

First, it's overpriced for what it is.... and while I guess that's expected for being IN the ballpark technically, if you pay $13 for a burger or sandwich, it ought to come with fries or a salad. Even a mentally challenged 8 year old could tell you that. I get that you can overcharge the tourists that invade SOMA every game night. But how about a neighborhood special? Free fries on non-game nights with your meal? Half off apps or beers? Throw us a frickin bone here!!!

Second, and here's a major public health concern, as well as a giant waste of effort by servers/staff- don't set out open containers of ketchup, mustard, and other things and then leave them at tables for anyone to dip in, spit or sneeze on, or otherwise violate. Just leave the frickin bottles. That's pretty much common sense and is kind of disgusting. Next time I'm asking for the bottle, especially if it's after a game. It may seem petty to some, but trust me, people are going to get sick from this.

Now the pros: I really like the space- it's cool, it's hip, it's got a ton of TVs in one area if that's what you want, as well as some outdoor space and ample bar area with high ceilings and a comfortable vibe. Also, while the menu wasn't as varied as I thought it could have been (salads? veggie sandwich option? fancy soft pretzels?), the food was pretty good and I thought for the people they are catering to the menu items are appropriate. The food isn't greasy but it's not health food either- it's what you'd expect the ballgame crowd would be looking for- homey American comfort food, plus a few extras. I had the falafel platter which I enjoyed- soft fresh falafel with good seasoning, and an awesome cucumber sauce- salad and pita could have been better. (Not a TON of veggie options, but it'll do). They just need to make the servings of fries bigger already- the large was like the size of my hand. Why so stingy? 

Overall, this place is a good option on a non-game night  (otherwise it will probably be obnoxiously packed) if you don't mind paying a little extra. Good addition to the neighborhood- that is, if they consider my requests!! :-)
author: Kristen L.

description:
Beers here are overpriced!
Fish and chips - served with hair in them - YUK!
Server actually had his thumb in my tartare sauce when he put the plate on the table.

1 star because my dog could sit on the patio with me.
Will not be back!
author: pb ..

description: Pregaming here before a Giants game. We always have our section on the patio! Gets really crowd but is worth it. Bartenders are so nice and pour with a heavy hand :)  Great place for big groups.
author: Lola D.

description:
Solid sports bar... or more specifically, Giants bar.  I went here to watch game one of the NL playoffs on a Saturday.  I arrived about 15 minutes before the game started and the bar was full but not totally packed (during the Series games it was at capacity with a line to get in).  It took about ten minutes to get drinks at the bar but that is to be expected when a bar is that full.  And really, that's what we went for--to watch the game in a crowd full of Giants fans!

There is a lot of standing room and counter space so you can set food or drinks down while you stand and watch the game.  I was particularly impressed with the fact that the waitress took food and drink orders from the standing room only area.  Maybe this is par for the course at sports bars (I am new to the sports bar scene)?  I've never seen that at a bar before, and thought it was fantastic that we didn't have to leave our spot and wait at the bar to get more beers.  The waitress was also courteous and efficient, an impressive feat given how crowded the bar was.  

Because of the crowd we had trouble finding a place next to a counter or table.  But when we did order food we negotiated with some friendly folks near us who were next to counter space to put our food down in our area.  Friendly fellow patrons are always a plus.  We had the nachos and they were yummy.

I had a great time there and will go back again for Giants games.  The crowd is friendly, the space is big, and they have a great bar menu.  Oh, and I suppose I should also mention the TV situation.  AMAZING.  There are panels of TVs on every wall, so no matter what direction I looked I could watch the game on at least two monitors.  Ideal set up, since you can turn to talk to your friends and still not miss a play.
author: Meredith H.

description: There is nothing particularly bad about the food or drink here; I am giving it one star because of one of their bouncers. It was Game 3 of the World Series, a shutout too mind you, and right as the Giants won a "Let's go Giants, Fuck Detroit" chant breaks out--and one of their bouncers has the nerve to tell us to stop because "there are kids here". In a bar/grill. At the ballpark. In San Francisco, where statistically speaking there are hardly any kids due to the high cost of living. I didn't wait that long in line to get into the Disney store, dammit. Never coming back.
author: Tony P.

description: I had the food and I'm still going to keep it at 4 stars. They only serve food after 5pm so they're useless to me at lunchtime. The pulled pork sliders were okay and the nachos (from mijitas) were decent. Mostly it's the location and atmosphere I like. Also, the drinks are a bit pricey with no happy hour menu to help out....
author: Andrea B.

description: If your going to a giants game I think this is a good place to hang out before the game. Decent prices compared to inside the stadium, though I'm not sure I would make this my first choice on any other day.
author: Jason R.

description:
It is a massive improvement from Acme Chophouse. When there is no game, it's nice to hang out. They have a great selection of beer, good beer, microbrews and imports. The food is decent. If they would do some neighborhood specials for the locals, I would visit more often. 

Have not attempted to go on a game night, watched one away game from Mijita next door. It was a good crowd but hardly any space to breathe.
author: J M.

description: I went here for a late night dinner and drinks since I live a few blocks away. Food and drinks are decent enough, I'd imagine it's all the more fun during baseball season.
author: T. M.

description:
I saw looking forward to vist the Public House.  We tried it three times.  The food was adverage and service bad.  The  hot dog was an insult to Willie Mays and the Giants.   
Tlhe staff was rude.  I felt I was violating their party. Plates were tossed at us.  Request for water seem lik and insult. 
On our second visit we recieved the wrong order but before we could inform the server left.   The thrid visit continue to have very bad food (hot food served cold - presentation rushed at the least)  The burger was over cooked.

Noise level was higher that I expected.
author: Fred H.

description:
My husband and I came here last night before the game and we were lucky enough to score a table right away.  I've read reviews about the slow service but that's not what I witnessed last night. The waitress was very nice and she took the time to answer our questions.  

We had the lamb sliders (3 for $9) for starters which were tasty but the meat to bun ratio is way off, too much bun and not enough meat.  We also had the chicken pot pie (Monday night special $18.00) which was big enough for 2 people to share. The pot pie had nice chunky pieces of chicken and the veggies had a nice bite to it.  

I love the beer selection here, they offer a variety that you don't find everywhere else.
author: Tina A.

description: Great place for a beer and chow before the Giants game. We went on a Friday afternoon and got there just as they opened (4 pm). Not really sure why they don't open earlier, but we got good seats at the bar. If you get there after 5 pm, don't plan on having a seat. This place gets crazy busy! I would never go here unless I got here early, just not worth it to me. We ordered an appetizer, and then two meals. Food was good, but this place is not cheap. Throw in a few beers and we paid over $100 for two people. The experience was well worth the price of admission! Walking into the stadium from the bar is pretty cool too.
author: Jerry L.

description:
I want to like this place but can't. 

It seems to have a nice atmosphere, interesting menu and looks nice, but I have not been able to get service at a table. 

I have only gone for food twice, and both times were on game days. They were crowded but not overcrowded. Both times I had a table and both times I was unable to get service. The first time I waited 20 minutes. The second time I waited 10.  As I left, the nice busboy/man (who notified the waitress that I had been sitting there for 10 minutes but was unsuccessful in getting her attention to my table either) shrugged in his understanding. 

I am resigned to eat elsewhere and stop in for a beer to go (into the stadium) before I watch the game. The beers are wonderful, they are cheaper than the rip-offs in the stadium, and I can get service at the bar.
author: David K.

description: Went here before a Giants game to catch a quick drink and some food. It was me, my girlfriend, and another couple. The place wasn't packed which surprised me. After sitting at a table, it took about 15-20mins to be greeted. We were stuck with one food menu but given four drink menus. Three out of the four orders were incorrect and when we told the food server, she was very rude about it like it was our fault. I'm not sure if the waitress was intimidated by our good looks but she checked on us just once. We had to flag down servers for refills and to get our bill. When we were finally able to ask for our bill, I asked if it could be split. Of course it wasn't. I had asked for BBQ sauce on my chicken sandwich instead of the usual cheese, avocado, and lettuce only to find out I was charged a dollar for it. One dollar isn't a big deal but the fact that I was never told it would be extra and the fact that I didn't get any other toppings and not to mention my order was wrong to begin with, I was a little annoyed!! I definitely won't be back. There are too many other good bars/restaurants around the stadium for me to spend my money. Don't waste your money here unless you like bad service.
author: steve r.
